original: Yena vā kayirate, yena vā passati, yena vā suṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ karaṇasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yena vā yena vā passati yena vā suṇāti tam kārakam karaṇa saññam hoti
translated: The place where something is done, the place where something is seen, the place where something is heard, is called the place of the action.

original: Dattena vihiṃ lunāti, vāsiyā kaṭṭhaṃ tacchati, pharasunā rukkhaṃ chindati, kudālena pathaviṃ khaṇati, satthena kammaṃ karoti. Cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati.
analyzed: dattena vihim lunāti vāsiyā kaṭṭham tacchati pharasunā rukkham chindati kudālena pathavim khaṇati satthena kammam karoti cakkhunā rūpam passati
translated: He injures with a stick, he cuts wood with an axe, he cuts down a tree with a saw, he digs the earth with a spade, he does work with a knife, he sees visible objects with the eye.

analyzed: karaṇam iccanena kvatthaḥ karaṇe tatiyā
translated: When the meaning of “instrument” is intended, the instrumental case is used.

analyzed: yam karoti tam kammam
translated: The instrument is the instrument of the action.

original: Yaṃ vā karoti, yaṃ vā passati, yaṃ vā suṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ kammasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yam vā karoti yam vā passati yam vā suṇāti tam kārakam kamma saññam hoti
translated: The instrument by which something is done, the instrument by which something is seen, the instrument by which something is heard, is called the instrument of the action.

original: Chattaṃ karoti, rathaṃ karoti, rūpaṃ passati, saddaṃ suṇāti, kaṇṭakaṃ maddati, visaṃ gilati.
analyzed: chattam karoti ratham karoti rūpam passati saddam suṇāti kaṇṭakam maddati visam gilati
translated: He makes an umbrella, he makes a chariot, he sees a visible object, he hears a sound, he presses a thorn, he swallows poison.

original: Kammamiccanena kvattho? Kammatthe dutiyā.🔽281, 294. Yo karoti sa kattā.
analyzed: kammamiccanena kvatthaḥ kamma atthe dutiyā  yaḥ karoti sa kattā
translated: By the desire to express the doing, the kvatth is in the sense of the doing.🔽The one who does is the doer.

analyzed: yaḥ karoti saḥ kattu saññaḥ hoti
translated: The one who does is the one who has the idea of the doer.

original: Ahinā daṭṭho naro, garuḷena hato nāgo. Buddhena jito māro, upaguttena māro bandho.
analyzed: ahinā daṭṭhaḥ naraḥ garuḷena hataḥ nāgaḥ buddhena jitaḥ māraḥ upaguttena māraḥ bandho
translated: A man bitten by a snake, an elephant struck by a garuḍa, Māra vanquished by the Buddha, Māra bound by Upagupta.

analyzed: kattu iccanena kvatthaḥ kattari ca
translated: By the desire to express the doing, the kvatth is in the sense of the doing.

analyzed: yaḥ sa hetu
translated: The one who causes to do is the cause.

original: Yo kattāraṃ kāreti, so hetusañño hoti, kattā ca.
analyzed: yaḥ kattāram kāreti saḥ hetu saññaḥ hoti kattā ca
translated: The one who causes the doer to do is the one who has the idea of the cause, and the doer.

original: So puriso taṃ purisaṃ kammaṃ kāreti so puriso tena purisena kammaṃ kāreti, so puriso tassa purisassa kammaṃ kāreti. Evaṃ hāreti pāṭheti pāceti, dhāreti.
analyzed: so purisaḥ tam purisam kammam kāreti saḥ purisaḥ tena purisena kammam kāreti saḥ purisaḥ tassa purisassa kammam kāreti evam hāreti pāṭheti pāceti dhāreti
translated: That man causes that man to do the deed, that man causes that man to do the deed by that man, that man causes the deed of that man. So also he causes to carry, he causes to cook, he causes to bear.

original: Hetuiccanena kvattho? Dhātūhi ṇe ṇaya ṇāpe ṇāpayā kāritāni hetvatthe.🔽283, 316. Yassa vā pariggaho taṃ sāmī.
analyzed: hetu iccanena kvatthaḥ dhātūhi ṇe ṇaya ṇāpe ṇāpayā kāritāni hetu atthe  yassa vā pariggahaḥ tam sāmī
translated: By the desire to express the cause, the kvatth is in the sense of the cause.🔽The one who has the possession is the owner.

original: Yassa vā pariggaho, taṃ sāmīsaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yassa vā pariggahaḥ tam sāmīsaññam hoti
translated: The one who has the possession is the one who has the idea of the owner.

original: Tassa bhikkhuno paṭivīso, tassa bhikkhuno patto, tassa bhikkhuno cīvaraṃ, attano mukhaṃ.
analyzed: tassa bhikkhuno paṭivīsaḥ tassa bhikkhuno patto tassa bhikkhuno cīvaram attanaḥ mukham
translated: The other monk’s bowl, the other monk’s robe, the other monk’s face.

original: Sāmīiccanena kvattho? Sāmismiṃ chaṭṭhī.🔽284, 283. Liṅgatthe paṭhamā.
analyzed: sāmī it canena kvatthaḥ sāmismin chaṭṭhī  liṅga tthe paṭhamā
translated: The sixth case is used to show possession.🔽The first case is used to show gender.

analyzed: liṅga attha abhidhāna matte paṭhamā vibhatti
translated: The first case is used to show the mere gender of a noun.

original: Puriso, purisā, eko, dve, ca, vā, he, ahe, re, are.
analyzed: purisaḥ purisā ekaḥ dve ca vā he ahe re are
translated: Man, men; one, two; and, or; he, they; this, these; oh, ohs.

analyzed: ālapane ca
translated: The first case is used in addressing.

original: Ālapanatthā dhike liṅgatthābhidhānamatte ca paṭhamāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: ālapana tthāḥ dhike liṅga tthā abhidhāna matte ca paṭhamā vibhatti
translated: The first case is used in addressing and in showing the mere gender of a noun.

original: Bho purisa, bhavanto purisā, bho rāja, bhavanto rājāno, he sakhe, he sakhino.
analyzed: bho purisa bhavanto purisāḥ bho rāja bhavantaḥ rājānaḥ he sakhe he sakhinaḥ
translated: Oh, man; ohs, men; oh, king; ohs, kings; he, friend; he, friends.

analyzed: karaṇe tatiyā
translated: The third case is used to show the instrument.

analyzed: karaṇa kārake tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The third case is used to show the instrument.

original: Agginā kuṭiṃ jhāpeti, manasā ce paduṭṭhena, manasā ce pasannena, kāyena kammaṃ karoti.🔽287, 299. Sahādiyoge ca.
analyzed: agginā kuṭim jhāpeti manasā ce paduṭṭhena manasā ce pasannena kāyena kammam karoti  saha ādi yoge ca
translated: Fire burns a hut; if the mind is corrupted; if the mind is serene; one does an action with the body.🔽The third case is used to show association.

analyzed: saha ādi yoga tthe ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The third case is used to show association.

original: Sahāpi gaggena saṅgho uposathaṃ kareyya, vināpi gaggena, mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ, sahassena samaṃ mitā.
analyzed: saha api gaggena saṅghaḥ uposatham kareyya vinā api gaggena mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim sahassena samam mitā
translated: The Sangha can do the observance-day ceremony with Gagga, without Gagga, with a large Sangha of monks, with a thousand, with an equal number.

analyzed: kattari ca
translated: And with the instrumental case.

analyzed: kattari ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The instrumental case is used.

original: Raññā hato poso, yakkhena dinno varo, ahinā daṭṭho naro.
analyzed: raññā hataḥ posaḥ yakkhena dinnaḥ varaḥ ahinā daṭṭhaḥ naraḥ
translated: A person is killed by a king, a boon is given by a spirit, a man is bitten by a snake.

analyzed: hetu atthe ca
translated: And with the cause.

analyzed: hetu atthe ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The instrumental case is used.

original: Annena vasati, dhammena vasati, vijjāya vasati, sakkārena vasati.
analyzed: annena vasati dhammena vasati vijjāya vasati sakkārena vasati
translated: One lives by food, one lives by the Dhamma, one lives by knowledge, one lives by respect.

analyzed: sattamī atthe ca  sattamī atthe ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: And with the locative case.🔽The instrumental case is used.

original: Tena kālena, tena samayena. (Yena kālena, yena samayena,) tena kho pana samayena.
analyzed: tena kālena tena samayena yena kālena yena samayena tena kho pana samayena
translated: At that time, on that occasion. (At that time, on that occasion,) then at that time.

analyzed: yena aṅga vikāraḥ
translated: And with the change of a body part.

original: Yena byādhimatā aṅgena aṅgino vikāro lakkhīyate. Tattha tatiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: yena byādhimatā aṅgena aṅginaḥ vikāraḥ lakkhīyate tattha tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The instrumental case is used to show the change of a body part that is sick.

original: Akkhinā kāṇo, hatthena kuṇī, kāṇaṃ passati nettena, pādena khañjo, piṭṭhiyā khujjo.
analyzed: akkhinā kāṇaḥ hatthena kuṇī kāṇam passati nettena pādena khañjaḥ piṭṭhiyā khujjaḥ
translated: One is one-eyed in the eye, one is lame in the hand, one sees with the eye, one is lame in the foot, one is crooked in the back.

analyzed: visesane ca
translated: And with the specification.

analyzed: visesana atthe ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: And the instrumental case is used in the sense of distinction.

original: Gottena gotamo nātho, suvaṇṇena abhirūpo, tapasā uttamo.
analyzed: gottena gotamaḥ nāthaḥ suvaṇṇena abhirūpaḥ tapasā uttamaḥ
translated: “The protector by the Gotama clan, the handsome one by the Suvanna clan, the best one by the ascetic clan.”

analyzed: sampadāne catutthī
translated: The fourth case is used in the sense of accomplishment.

analyzed: sampadāna kārake catutthī vibhatti hoti
translated: The fourth case is used in the sense of the accomplishing agent.

original: Buddhassa vā dhammassa vā saṅghassa vā dānaṃ deti, dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā.
analyzed: buddhassa vā dhammassa vā saṅghassa vā dānam deti dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā
translated: “He gives a gift to the Buddha, to the Dhamma, or to the Saṅgha, he is a giver to the ascetic or to the brahmin.”

analyzed: namaḥ yoga ādīsu api ca
translated: , . And also in the sense of saluting, etc.

analyzed: namaḥ yoga ādīsu api ca catutthī vibhatti hoti
translated: And the fourth case is used in the sense of saluting, etc.

original: Namo te buddha vīratthu, sotthi pajānaṃ, namo karohi nāgassa, svāgataṃ te mahārāja.
analyzed: namaḥ te buddha sotthi pajānam namaḥ karohi nāgassa svāgatam te mahā rāja
translated: “Salute you, O Buddha, O hero, the people are safe, salute the elephant, welcome to you, great king.”

analyzed: apādāne pañcamī
translated: , . The fifth case is used in the sense of separation.

analyzed: apādāna kārake pañcamī vibhatti
translated: The fifth case is used in the sense of the separating agent.

original: Pāpā cittaṃ nivāraye, abbhā muttova candimā, bhayā muccati so naro.
analyzed: cittam nivāraye abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā bhayā muccati saḥ naraḥ
translated: “Keep the mind away from evil, like the moon from the clouds, that man is freed from fear.”

analyzed: kāraṇa tthe ḍha
translated: , . The sixth case is used in the sense of reason.

analyzed: kāraṇa atthe ca pañcamī vibhatti hoti
translated: And the sixth case is used in the sense of reason.

original: Ananubodhā appaṭivedhā catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ adassanā.🔽297, 284. Kammatthe dutiyā.
analyzed: ananubodhā appaṭivedhā catunnam ariya saccānam yathābhūtam a dassanā  kammatthe dutiyā
translated: “Because of not understanding, not penetrating, not seeing as it really is the four noble truths.”🔽, . The second case is used in the sense of action.

analyzed: kammatthe dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The second case is used in the sense of action.

original: Gāvaṃ hanati, vīhayo lunāti, satthaṃ karoti, ghaṭaṃ karoti, rathaṃ karoti, dhammaṃ suṇāti, buddhaṃ pūjeti, vācaṃ bhāsatī, taṇḍulaṃ vacati, coraṃ ghāteti.🔽298, 287. Kāladdhānamaccantasaṃyoge.
analyzed: gāvam hanati vīhayaḥ lunāti sattham karoti ghaṭam karoti ratham karoti dhammam suṇāti buddham pūjeti vācam bhāsatī taṇḍulam vacati coram ghāteti  kāla d dhāna mac canta saṃyoge
translated: He kills a cow, he threshes the rice, he makes a knife, he makes a pot, he makes a chariot, he listens to the Dhamma, he worships the Buddha, he speaks a speech, he threshes the rice, he kills a thief.🔽The locative case is used with the indeclinable ‘accantasaṃyoga’.

analyzed: kāla ddhānam a c c anta saṃyoge dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The locative case is used with the indeclinable ‘accantasaṃyoga’.

original: Māsaṃ maṃsodanaṃ bhuñjati, saradaṃ ramaṇīyā nadī, māsaṃ sajjhāyati, yojanaṃ vanarāji, yojanaṃ dīgho pabbato, kosaṃ sajjhāyati.
analyzed: māsam maṃsodanam bhuñjati saradam ramaṇīyā nadī māsam sajjhāyati yojanam vana rāji yojanam dīghaḥ pabbataḥ kosam sajjhāyati
translated: He eats meat for a month, the river is delightful for the autumn, he recites for a month, the forest-line is a yojana, the mountain is long a yojana, he recites the treasury.

original: Accantasaṃyogeti kimatthaṃ? Saṃvacchare bhojanaṃ bhuñjati.🔽299, 288. Kammappavadhanīyayutte.
analyzed: a c c anta saṃyoga iti kimattham saṃvacchare bhojanam bhuñjati  kamma ppavadhanīya yutte
translated: Why is ‘accantasaṃyoga’ said? He eats food for a year.🔽The locative case is used with the indeclinable ‘kammappavacanīyayutta’.

analyzed: kammappavacanīya yutte dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The locative case is used with the indeclinable ‘kammappavacanīyayutta’.

original: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato, pabbajitamanupabbajiṃsu.
analyzed: tam kha pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ pabbajitam anupabbajiṃsu
translated: Now, good sirs, this good report about Master Gotama has spread: ‘He is a Buddha, perfected and fully awakened …’ He has gone forth from the house life into homelessness.

original: 300, 286. Gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara sayādīnaṃ kārite vā.
translated: The locative case is used with the indeclinable ‘gati’ and with the indeclinables ‘buddhi’, ‘bhuja’, ‘paṭha’, ‘hara’, ‘kara’, ‘sayā’, etc. in the sense of ‘doing’.

original: Gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara sayādīnaṃ payoge kārite dutiyāvibhatti hoti vā.
analyzed: gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara saya ādīnam payoge kārite dutiyā vibhatti vā
translated: In the case of the verbs buddhi, bhuja, paṭha, hara, kara, sayā, etc., the second case is used optionally.

original: Puriso purisaṃ (gāmaṃ) gāmayati, puriso purisena vā, puriso purisassa vā. Evaṃ bodhayati, bhojayati, pāṭhayati, hārayati, kārayati, sayāpayati. Evaṃ sabbattha kārite.
analyzed: purisaḥ purisam gāmam gāmayati purisaḥ purisena vā purisaḥ purisassa vā evam bodhayati bhojayati pāṭhayati hārayati kārayati sa yāpayati evam sabbattha kārite
translated: A man causes a man to go to the village, a man causes a man to go with a man, a man causes a man to go for a man. He causes him to understand, to eat, to read, to carry, to do, to lie down. So in all cases of causing.

analyzed: sāmismin chaṭṭhī
translated: The sixth case is used in the sense of “belonging to.”

analyzed: sāmismin chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: The sixth case is used in the sense of “belonging to.”

original: Tassa bhikkhuno paṭivīso, tassa bhikkhuno patto, tassa bhikkhuno cīvaraṃ, attano mukhaṃ.
analyzed: tassa bhikkhuno paṭivīsaḥ tassa bhikkhuno patto tassa bhikkhuno cīvaram attanaḥ mukham
translated: The portion of that bhikkhu, the bowl of that bhikkhu, the robe of that bhikkhu, his own mouth.

analyzed: okāse sattamī
translated: The seventh case is used in the sense of “occasion.”

analyzed: okāsa kārake sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: The seventh case is used in the sense of “occasion.”

original: Gambhīre odakantike, pāpasmiṃ ramati mano, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati kulaputto.🔽303, 321. Sāmissarādhipati dāyāda sakkhīpatibhū pasutakusalehi ca.
analyzed: gambhīre odakantike pāpasmim ramati manaḥ bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati kula putto  dāyāda sakkhī pati bhū pasuta kusalehi ca
translated: In the deep water, in the vicinity, in the wicked, the mind delights. In the Blessed One, a clansman lives the spiritual life.

original: Sāmī issara adhipati dāyāda sakkhīpatibhū pasutakusala iccetehi payoge chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca.
analyzed: sāmī issara adhipati dāyāda sakkhī patibhū pasuta kusala icca etehi payoge chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca
translated: The sixth case is used with the words “master,” “lord,” “owner,” “heir,” “witness,” “rival,” and “skilled” in the sense of “belonging to,” and the seventh case is used.

original: Goṇānaṃ sāmī, goṇesu sāmī, goṇānaṃ issaro, goṇesu issaro. Goṇānaṃ adhipati, goṇesu🔽adhipati. Goṇānaṃ dāyādo, goṇesu dāyādo. Goṇānaṃ sakkhī, goṇesu sakkhī, goṇānaṃ patibhū,
analyzed: goṇānam sāmī goṇesu sāmī goṇānam issaraḥ goṇesu issaraḥ goṇānam adhipatiḥ goṇesu  adhipati goṇānam dāyādaḥ goṇesu dāyādaḥ goṇānam sakkhī goṇesu sakkhī goṇānam pati bhū
translated: He is the owner of the cattle, the owner of the cows, the owner of the bulls, the owner of the steers, the owner of the heifers, the owner of the young oxen, the owner of the goats, the owner of the sheep, the owner of the chickens, the owner of the slaves, the owner of the servants. He is the lord of the cattle, the lord of the cows, the lord of the bulls, the lord of the steers, the lord of the heifers, the lord of the young oxen, the lord of the goats, the lord of the sheep, the lord of the chickens, the lord of the slaves, the lord of the servants.

original: goṇesu patibhū. Goṇānaṃ pasuto, goṇesu pasuto. Goṇānaṃ kusalo, goṇesu kusalo.
analyzed: goṇesu patibhū goṇānam pasutaḥ goṇesu pasutaḥ goṇānam kusalaḥ goṇesu kusalaḥ
translated: The owner of the oxen, the owner in the oxen, the lord of the oxen, the lord in the oxen. The master of the oxen, the master in the oxen. The heir of the oxen, the heir in the oxen. The witness of the oxen, the witness in the oxen. The counterpart of the oxen, the counterpart in the oxen. The one skilled in oxen, the one skilled in the oxen.

analyzed: niddhāraṇe ca
translated: , . In the sense of ‘holding back’.

original: Niddhāraṇatthe ca chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca.🔽Kaṇhā gāvīnaṃ sampannakhīratamā, kaṇhā gāvīsu sampannakhīratamā. Sāmā nārīnaṃ dassanīyatamā,
analyzed: niddhāraṇa atthe ca chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca  kaṇhā gāvīnam sampanna khīratamā kaṇhā gāvīsu sampanna khīratamā sāmā nārīnam dassanīyatamā
translated: The sixth and seventh case endings are used in the sense of ‘holding back’.

original: sāmā nārīsu dassanīyatamā. Manussānaṃ khattiyo sūratamo, manussesu khattiyo sūratamo.
analyzed: sāmā nārīsu dassanīyatamā manussānam khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ manussesu khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ
translated: The black cow is the best at producing milk among the cows, the black cow is the best at producing milk among the cows. The fair woman is the most beautiful among the women, the fair woman is the most beautiful among the women. The warrior is the most courageous among men, the warrior is the most courageous among men.

original: Pathikānaṃ dhāvanto sīghatamo, pathikesu dhāvanto sīghatamo.
analyzed: pathikānam dhāvantaḥ sīghatamaḥ pathikesu dhāvantaḥ sīghatamaḥ
translated: The runner is the fastest among the runners, the runner is the fastest among the runners.

analyzed: an ādare ca
translated: , . And in the sense of ‘disrespect’.

analyzed: an ādare chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca
translated: The sixth and seventh case endings are used in the sense of ‘disrespect’.

original: Rudato dārakassa pabbaji, rudantasmiṃ dārake pabbaji.
analyzed: rudataḥ dārakassa pabbaji rudantasmin dārake pabbaji
translated: The monk went forth while the boy was crying, the monk went forth while the boy was crying.

analyzed: kvaci dutiyā chaṭṭhī nam atthe
translated: Sometimes in the sixth case.

analyzed: chaṭṭhīnam atthe kvaci dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: Sometimes in the sixth case the second case is used.

original: Apissu maṃ aggivessana tisso upamā paṭibhaṃsu.
analyzed: mama aggivessana tissaḥ upamā
translated: And three similes occurred to me, Aggivessana.

analyzed: tatiyā sattamī nañ ca
translated: And sometimes in the third and seventh cases.

original: Tatiyāsattamīnaṃ atthe ca kvaci dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamīnam atthe ca kvaci dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: Sometimes in the third and seventh cases the second case is used.

original: Sace maṃ samaṇo gotamo ālapissati, tvañca maṃ nābhibhāsasi. Evaṃ tatiyatthe.
analyzed: sace mam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ālapissati tvam ca mama na abhibhāsasi evam tatiya tthe
translated: If the recluse Gotama speaks to me, but you do not address me, then in the third case.

original: Pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā. Evaṃ sattamyatthe.
analyzed: pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā ekam samayam bhagavā evam sattamī atthe
translated: Having dressed in the morning time, at one time the Lord. Then in the seventh case.

analyzed: chaṭṭhī ca
translated: And sometimes in the sixth case.

original: Tatiyāsattamīnaṃ atthe ca kvaci chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamīnam atthe ca kvaci chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: Sometimes in the third and seventh cases the sixth case is used.

original: Kato me kalyāṇo, kataṃ me pāpaṃ. Evaṃ tatiyatthe.
analyzed: kataḥ me kalyāṇaḥ katam me pāpam evam tatiyatthe
translated: Good has been done by me, evil has been done by me. Then in the third case.

original: Kusalā naccagītassa sikkhitā cāturitthiyo, kusalo tvaṃ rathassa aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ. Evaṃ sattamyatthe.
analyzed: kusalā nacca gītassa sikkhitā cāturitthiyaḥ kusalaḥ tvam rathassa aṅga paccaṅgānam evam sattamī atthe
translated: Skilled in the dance and song are the four women, you are skilled in the parts and the minor parts of a chariot. Then in the seventh case.

original: Kvacīti kimatthaṃ? Yo vo ānanda mayā dhammo ca vinayo ca desito paññatto, ānando atthesu vicakkhaṇo.
analyzed: kvaci iti kimattham yaḥ vaḥ ānanda mayā dhammo ca vinayo ca desito paññattaḥ ānandaḥ atthesu vicakkhaṇo
translated: Sometimes—what is the point of that? The Dhamma and Discipline, Ananda, that has been shown by me to you, being seen, Ananda, is well seen by you.

analyzed: dutiyā pañcamī nañca
translated: And in the second and fifth cases.

analyzed: dutiyā pañcamīnam ca atthe kvaci chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: And in the second and fifth cases the sixth case is sometimes used.

original: Tassa bhavanti vattāro, sahasā kammassa kattāro, evaṃ dutiyatthe.
analyzed: tassa bhavanti vattāraḥ sahasā kammassa kattāraḥ evam dutiya tthe
translated: His followers, his doers of deeds, his doers of deeds rashly. Thus in the second case.

original: Assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, kinnu kho ahaṃ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, sabbe tasanti
analyzed: a ssavana tā dhammassa parihāyanti kinnu kho aham tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi sabbe tasanti
translated: Not hearing the Dhamma, they are falling away. Why should I fear that happiness? All fear

original: daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno, bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ, bhāyāmi
analyzed: daṇḍassa sabbe bhāyanti maccunaḥ bhītaḥ catunnam āsīvisānam ghora visānam bhāyāmi
translated: the rod. All fear death. Fearing the four snakes with virulent poison, I fear

original: ghoravisassa nāgassa. Evaṃ pañcamyatthe.🔽310, 324. Kamma karaṇa nimittatthesu sattamī.
analyzed: ghora visassa nāgassa evam pañcamī atthe  kamma karaṇa nimitta atthesu sattamī
translated: the virulent-poisoned snake. Thus in the fifth case.🔽In the seventh case in the sense of action, instrument, and reason.

analyzed: kamma karaṇa nimitta atthesu sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: In the seventh case is used in the sense of action, instrument, and reason.

original: Sundarāvuso ime ājīvakā bhikkhūsu abhivādenti. Evaṃ kammatthe.
analyzed: sundara āvuso ime ājīvakāḥ bhikkhūsu abhivādenti evam kammatthe
translated: “Friends, these Ājīvakas salute the bhikkhus.” Thus in the sense of action.

original: Hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti, pattesu piṇḍāya caranti, pathesu gacchanti. Evaṃ karaṇatthe.
analyzed: hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti pattesu piṇḍāya caranti pathesu gacchanti evam karaṇa tthe
translated: They walk for alms in the hands, they walk for alms in the feet, they go in the paths. Thus in the sense of instrument.

original: Dīpi cammesu haññate, kuñjaro dantesu haññate, evaṃ nimittatthe.
analyzed: dīpi cammesu haññate kuñjaraḥ dantesu haññate evam nimitta atthe
translated: In the skins of lizards he is killed, in the tusks of elephants he is killed. Thus in the sense of reason.

analyzed: sampadāne ca
translated: And in the sense of accomplishment.

analyzed: sampadāne ca sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: And the locative case is used in the sense of the instrumental.

original: Saṅghe dinnaṃ mahapphala, saṅghe gotamī dehi, saṅghe te dinne ahañceva pūjito bhavissāmi.🔽312, 326. Pañcamyatthe ca.
analyzed: saṅghe dinnam mahapphala saṅghe gotamī dehi saṅghe te dinne aham ca iva pūjitaḥ bhavissāmi      ca
translated: “Given to the Community is of great fruit. Give to the Community, Gotamī. When given to the Community, I will be honoured.”

analyzed: pañcamī atthe ca sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: And the locative case is used in the sense of the fifth case.

analyzed: kadalīsu gaje rakkhanti  kāla bhāvesu ca
translated: “They guard the elephants in the banana plants.”🔽And the locative case is used in the sense of time.

original: Kālabhāvesu ca kattari payujjamāne sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: kāla bhāvesu ca kattari payujjamāne sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: When used in the sense of an agent, the locative case is used in the sense of time.

original: Pubbaṇhasamaye gato, sāyanhasamaye āgato. Bhikkhūsu bhojīyamānesu gato, bhuttesu āgato. Gosuduyhamānesu gato, duddhāsu āgato.
analyzed: pubbaṇha samaye gataḥ sāyanha samaye āgataḥ bhikkhūsu bhojīyamānesu gataḥ bhuttesu āgataḥ go su duyhamānesu gataḥ duddhāsu āgataḥ
translated: “He went at the time of dawn. He came at the time of evening. He went while the monks were being fed. He came when they had eaten. He went while the cows were being milked. He came when they had been milked.”

analyzed: upajha adhi kissara vacane
translated: And the locative case is used in the sense of the sixth case in the sense of “near” and “over”.

analyzed: upa adhi it ca itesam payoge adhika issara vacane sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: When used in the sense of “near”, the locative case is used in the sense of the sixth case in the sense of “over”.

original: Upa khāriyaṃ doṇo, upa nikkhe kahāpaṇaṃ. Adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, adhi naccesu gotamī, adhi devesu buddho.
analyzed: upa khāriyam doṇaḥ upa nikkhe kahāpaṇam adhi brahmadatte pañcālā adhi naccesu gotamī adhi devesu buddhaḥ
translated: “Near the cart, Doṇa. Near the house, put down the farthing. Over Brahmadatta, the Pañcālas. Over the dancers, Gotamī. Over the gods, the Buddha.”
And the locative case is used in the sense of the second case in the sense of “in order to”.

analyzed: maṇḍita aus suk ka i c ca ite su atthesu tatiyā vibhatti hoti sattamī ca
translated: The third and the seventh case- endings are used in the sense of adornment, eagerness, and desire.

original: Ñāṇena pasīdito, ñāṇasmiṃ vā pasīdito, ñāṇena ussukko, ñāṇasmiṃ vā ussukko tathāgato vā tathāgatagotto vā.
analyzed: ñāṇena pasīditaḥ ñāṇasmim vā pasīditaḥ ñāṇena ussukkaḥ ñāṇasmim vā ussukkaḥ tathāgataḥ vā tathāgata gottaḥ vā
translated: One who is pleased by knowledge, or one who is pleased in knowledge, or one who is eager by knowledge, or one who is eager in knowledge, is a Tathāgata or a descendant of the Tathāgatas.

analyzed: iti nāmakappe kārakakappaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ kaṇḍo
translated: Thus ends the sixth chapter in the presentation of the case- endings in the names of nouns.

analyzed: kāraka kappaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The chapter on the case-endings is concluded.

analyzed: samāsakappa
translated: Chapter on compounds

analyzed: sattama kaṇḍa
translated: Seventh chapter
. The compound is the meaning of the connection of names.

original: Tesaṃ nāmānaṃ payujjamānapadatthānaṃ yo yuttattho, so samāsasañño hoti.
analyzed: tesam nāmānam payujjamāna padatthānam yaḥ yutta atthaḥ saḥ samāsa saññaḥ hoti
translated: The meaning of the connection of those names, which are the meanings of the words used, is called a compound.

original: Kathinadussaṃ, āgantukabhattaṃ, jīvitindriyaṃ, samaṇabrāhmaṇā, sāriputtamoggallānā, brāhmaṇa gahapatikā.
analyzed: āgantuka bhattam jīvita indriyam samaṇa brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇa gahapatikā
translated: Hard cloth, food for visitors, the life faculty, ascetics and brahmins, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, brahmins and householders.

original: Nāmānamiti kimatthaṃ? Devadatto pacati, yaññadatto pacati.
analyzed: nāmānam iti kimattham devadatto pacati yaññadatto pacati
translated: Why is it said “of names”? Devadatta cooks, Yaññadatta cooks.

original: Yuttatthoti kimatthaṃ? Bhato rañño putto devadattassa.
analyzed: yutta attho ti kimattham bhato rañño putto devadattassa
translated: Why is it said “the meaning of the connection”? The son of the king, who is fed by Devadatta.

analyzed: samāsa e c canena kvatthaḥ kvaci samāsanta gata nama kāra antaḥ
translated: What is the purpose of the desire for a compound? In some places, the end of the word is not the reason for the end of the compound.

analyzed: tesam vibhattiyaḥ lopāḥ ca
translated: . Their case-endings are dropped.

original: Tesaṃ yuttatthānaṃ samāsānaṃ vibhattiyo lopā ca honti.
analyzed: tesam yutta tthānam samāsānam vibhattiyaḥ lopāḥ ca honti
translated: The case-endings, the sandhi, and the elisions of these are as follows.

analyzed: kathina dussam āgantuka bhattam
translated: Kathinadussaṃ, āgantukabhattaṃ.

original: Tesaṃgahaṇena samāsataddhitākhyātakitakānaṃ vibhattipaccayapadakkharāgamā ca lopā honti. Vāsiṭṭho, venateyyo.
analyzed: samāsa taddhita ākhyāta kitakānam vibhatti paccaya pada khara āgamāḥ ca lopāḥ honti vāsiṭṭhaḥ venateyyaḥ
translated: By the inclusion of these, the case-endings, the particles, and the elisions of the compounds, the nominal derivatives, the verb-forms, and the k-suffixes are as follows. Vāsiṭṭho, venateyyo.

original: Caggahaṇa mavadhāraṇatthaṃ, pabhaṅkaro, amataddado, medhaṅkaro, dīpaṅkaro.
analyzed: pabhaṅkaraḥ amataddadaḥ medhaṅkaraḥ dīpaṅkaraḥ
translated: The inclusion of the a-sign is for the purpose of restriction. Pabhaṅkaro, amataddado, medhaṅkaro, dīpaṅkaro.

analyzed: pakati cassa sarantassa
translated: The natural form of the word is for one who remembers.

original: Luttāsu vibhattīsu assa sarantassa liṅgassa pakatirūpāni honti.
analyzed: luttāsu vibhattīsu assa sarantassa liṅgassa pakati rūpāni honti
translated: In the elisions of the case-endings, the natural forms of the words are for one who remembers.

original: Cakkhusotaṃ, mukhanāsikaṃ, rājaputto, rājapuriso.🔽319, 330. Upasagganipātapubbako abyayībhāvo.
analyzed: cakkhu sotam mukha nāsikam rāja puttaḥ rāja purisaḥ  upasagga nipāta pubbakaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ
translated: Cakkhusotaṃ, mukhanāsikaṃ, rājaputto, rājapuriso.🔽The invariable compound is preceded by a prefix or a particle.

original: Upasagganipātapubbako samāso abyayībhāvasañño hoti.🔽Nagarassa samīpe pavattati kathā iti upanagaraṃ, darathānaṃ abhāvo niddarathaṃ, makasānaṃ
analyzed: upasagga nipāta pubbakaḥ samāsaḥ abyayībhāva saññaḥ hoti  nagarassa samīpe pavattati kathā iti upanagaram darathānam abhāvaḥ niddaratham makasānam
translated: The invariable compound is called such when it is preceded by a prefix or a particle.

original: abhāvo nimmakasaṃ, vuḍḍhānaṃ paṭipāṭi yathāvuḍḍhaṃ, ye ye vuḍḍhā vā yathāvuḍḍhaṃ,
analyzed: abhāvaḥ nimmakasam vuḍḍhānam paṭipāṭi yathāvuḍḍham ye ye vuḍḍhāḥ vā yathāvuḍḍham
translated: The talk that occurs near the city is upanagaraṃ, the absence of chariots is niddarathaṃ, the absence of ploughs is nimmakasaṃ, the order of the elders is yathāvuḍḍhaṃ, those who are elders or according to the elders is yathāvuḍḍhaṃ,

original: jīvassa yattako paricchedo yāvajīvaṃ, cittamadhikicca pavattanti te dhammāti adhicittaṃ,
analyzed: jīvassa yattakaḥ paricchedaḥ yāvajīvam cittam adhikicca pavattanti te dhammā ati adhicittam
translated: As far as the life-span of a living being extends, so far the thought occurs: thus ‘as long as life lasts’ is ‘as far as the thought occurs’.

original: pabbatassa tiro tiropabbataṃ, sotassa pati pavattati nāvā iti patisotaṃ, pāsādassa anto antopāsādaṃ.
analyzed: pabbatassa tiras tiropabbatam sotassa pati pavattati nāvā iti patisotam pāsādassa antar antopāsādam
translated: As far as the mountain is, so far the mountain is beyond: thus ‘as far as the mountain is’ is ‘beyond the mountain’. As far as the river is, so far the boat goes against the stream: thus ‘as far as the river is’ is ‘against the stream’. As far as the palace is, so far the palace is inside: thus ‘as far as the palace is’ is ‘inside the palace’.

analyzed: abyayībhāvam iccanena makāra antāḥ abyayībhāvāḥ
translated: Is the kvattha-word in the sense of indeclinability? The indeclinables are those that end in makāra and are not declined.

analyzed: saḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ
translated: It is of the neuter gender.

original: So abyayībhāvasamāso napuṃsakaliṅgova daṭṭhabbo.🔽Kumārīsu adhikicca pavattati kathā iti adhikumāri, vadhuyā samīpe pavattati kathā
analyzed: saḥ abyayībhāva samāsaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ uva daṭṭhabbo  kumārīsu adhikicca pavattati kathā iti adhikumāri vadhuyā samīpe pavattati kathā
translated: That indeclinable compound should be regarded as being of the neuter gender only.

original: iti upavadhu, gaṅgāya samīpe pavattati kathā iti upagaṅgaṃ, maṇikāya samīpe pavattati
analyzed: iti upavadhu gaṅgāya samīpe pavattati kathā iti upagaṅgam maṇikāya samīpe pavattati
translated: As far as maidens are, so far the talk occurs: thus ‘as far as maidens are’ is ‘about maidens’. As far as the bride is, so far the talk occurs: thus ‘as far as the bride is’ is ‘about the bride’. As far as the Ganges is, so far the talk occurs: thus ‘as far as the Ganges is’ is ‘about the Ganges’. As far as the Maṇika is, so far the talk occurs:

analyzed: kathā iti upamaṇikam
translated: thus ‘as far as the Maṇika is’ is ‘about the Maṇika’.🔽The singleness of the word in the case of the disaffected.

analyzed: samāsassa eka attam hoti napuṃsaka liṅga attam ca
translated: The singleness of the compound and its neuter gender are in the case of the disaffected.

original: Tayo lokā tilokaṃ, tayo daṇḍā tidaṇḍaṃ, tīṇi nayanāni tinayanaṃ, tayo siṅgā tisiṅgaṃ. Catasso disā catuddisaṃ, pañca indriyāni pañcindriyaṃ.
analyzed: tayaḥ lokā tilokam tayaḥ daṇḍā tidaṇḍam tīṇi nayanāni tinayanam tayaḥ siṅgā tisiṅgam catassaḥ disā catuddisam pañca indriyāni pañcindriyam
translated: The three worlds is the triple world ; the three staffs is the triple staff ; the three eyes is the triple eye ; the three horns is the triple horn . The four quarters is the four quarters ; the five faculties is the five faculties .

original: 322, 359. Tathā dvande pāṇi tūriya yoggasenaṅgakhuddajantuka vividhaviruddha visabhāgatthādīnañca.
analyzed: tathā
translated: Likewise in the compound pāṇi-tūriya-yoga-senāṅga-khuddaka-jantu-vividha-viruddha-visabhāga-attha, etc.,

original: Tathā dvande samāse pāṇi tūriya yogga senaṅgakhuddajantuka vividhaviruddha visabhāgatthaiccevamādīnaṃ ekattaṃ hoti, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca.🔽Taṃ yathā? Cakkhu ca sotañca cakkhusotaṃ, mukhañca nāsikā ca mukhanāsikaṃ, chavi ca maṃsañca lohitañca chavimaṃsalohitaṃ. Evaṃ pāṇyaṅgatthe.
analyzed: tathā dvande samāse ekattam hoti napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca  tam yathā cakkhu ca sotam ca cakkhu sotam mukham ca nāsikā ca mukha nāsikam chavi ca maṃsam ca lohitam ca chavi maṃsa lohitam evam pāṇi aṅga tthe
translated: Likewise in the compound pāṇi-tūriya-yoga-senāṅga-khuddaka-jantu-vividha-viruddha-visabhāga-attha-ekatta, etc., the meaning is singular and neuter.🔽How? Eye and ear are eye-and-ear ; face and nose are face-and-nose ; skin and flesh and blood are skin-flesh-and-blood . So in the sense of a part of the body.

original: Saṅkho ca paṇavo ca saṅkhapaṇavaṃ, gītañca vāditañca gītavāditaṃ, daddari ca ḍiṇḍimo ca daddariḍiṇḍimaṃ. Evaṃ tūriyaṅgatthe.
analyzed: saṅkhaḥ ca paṇavaḥ ca saṅkha paṇavam gītam ca vāditam ca gīta vāditam daddari ca ḍiṇḍimo ca daddari ḍiṇḍimam evam tūriyaṅga tthe
translated: Conch and cymbal are conch-and-cymbal ; song and musical instrument are song-and-musical-instrument ; tabor and kettledrum are tabor-and-kettledrum . So in the sense of a part of a musical instrument.

original: Phālo ca pācanañca phālapācanaṃ, yugañca naṅgalañca yuganaṅgalaṃ. Evaṃ yoggaṅgatthe.
analyzed: phālo ca pācanam ca phālapācanam yugam ca naṅgalam ca yuganaṅgalam evam
translated: And plough and burning are plough-burning. And yoke and plough are yoke-plough. So in the sense of a team.

original: Asi ca cammañca asicammaṃ, dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanukalāpaṃ, hatthī ca asso ca hatthiassaṃ, ratho ca pattiko ca rathapattikaṃ. Evaṃ senaṅgatthe.🔽Ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsamakasaṃ, kuntho ca kipilliko ca kunthakipillikaṃ, kīṭo ca sarīsapo ca kīṭasarīsapaṃ. Evaṃ khuddajantukatthe.
analyzed: asi ca cammam ca asi cammam dhanu ca kalāpaḥ ca dhanu kalāpam hatthī ca assaḥ ca hatthi assam rathaḥ ca pattikaḥ ca ratha pattikam evam senaṅgatthe  ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsa makasam kunthaḥ ca kipilliko ca kuntha kipillikam kīṭo ca sarīsapo ca kīṭa sarīsapam evam khudda jantukatthe
translated: And sword and hide are sword-hide. And bow and quiver are bow-quiver. And elephant and horse are elephant-horse. And chariot and foot-soldier are chariot-foot-soldier. So in the sense of an army.🔽And gadfly and mosquito are gadfly-mosquito. And thorn and jujube are thorn-jujube. And worm and lizard are worm-lizard. So in the sense of small creatures.

original: Ahi ca nakulo ca ahinakulaṃ, biḷāro ca mūsiko ca biḷāramūsikaṃ, kāko ca ulūko ca kākolūkaṃ. Evaṃ vividhaviruddhatthe.
analyzed: ahi ca nakulaḥ ca ahi nakulam biḷāro ca mūsikaḥ ca biḷāra mūsikam kāko ca ulūko ca kāka ulūkam evam vividha viruddha atthe
translated: And snake and mongoose are snake-mongoose. And cat and mouse are cat-mouse. And crow and owl are crow-owl. So in the sense of various opposites.

original: Sīlañca paññāṇañca sīlapaññāṇaṃ, samatho ca vipassanā ca samathavipassanaṃ, vijjā ca caraṇañca vijjācaraṇaṃ. Evaṃ visabhāgatthe.
analyzed: sīlam ca paññāṇam ca sīla paññāṇam samathaḥ ca vipassanā ca samatha vipassanam vijjā ca caraṇañca vijjā caraṇam evam visa bhāga tthe
translated: And virtue and understanding are virtue-understanding. And quiet and insight are quiet-insight. And knowledge and conduct are knowledge-conduct. So in the sense of unlike.

original: Ādiggahaṇaṃ kimatthaṃ? Dāsī ca dāso ca dāsidāsaṃ, itthī ca pumā ca itthipumaṃ, patto
analyzed: ādi gahaṇam kimattham dāsī ca dāsaḥ ca dāsi dāsam itthī ca pumā ca itthi pumam
translated: What is the point of the words ‘and so on’? Slave and slave are slave-slave. Woman and man are woman-man. Alms-food and lodging are alms-food-lodging. And so on.

original: ca cīvarañca pattacīvaraṃ, chattañca upāhanā ca chattupāhanaṃ, tikañca catukkañca🔽tikacatukkaṃ, veno ca rathakāro ca venarathakāraṃ, sākuṇiko ca māgaviko ca savakuṇikamāgavikaṃ,
analyzed: ca cīvarañca patta cīvaram chattañca upāhanā ca chattupāhanam tikañca catukkañca  tika catukkam venaḥ ca rathakāro ca vena rathakāram sākuṇikaḥ ca māgavikaḥ ca sa vakuṇika māgavikam
translated: And robe and bowl are bowl-and-robe. And sunshade and sandals are sunshade-and-sandals. And three and four are three-and-four. And lute and chariot-maker are lute-and-chariot-maker. And fowler and hunter are fowler-and-hunter. And long and medium are long-and-medium.

original: dīgho ca majjhimo ca dīghamajjhimaṃ iccevamādi.
analyzed: dīghaḥ ca majjhimaḥ ca dīgha majjhimam iti ca evamādi
translated: And so on.

original: 323, 360. Vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasukha na dhañña janapadādīnañca.
analyzed: vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasukha na dhañña janapada ādīnam ca
translated: The Vibhāsā is for tree, grass, cattle, wealth, grain, country, etc.

original: Rukkhatiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapadaiccevamādīnaṃ vibhāsā ekattaṃ hoti, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca
analyzed: vibhāsāḥ ekattam hoti napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca
translated: The Vibhāsā is for the singleness and neuter gender of tree, grass, cattle, wealth, grain, country, etc.,

original: dvande samāse. Assattho ca kapītano ca assatthakapītanaṃ, assatthakapītanā vā. Usīrañca🔽bīraṇañca usīrabīraṇaṃ, usīrabīraṇā vā. Ajo ca eḷako ca ajeḷakaṃ, ajeḷakā vā. Hiraññañca🔽suvaṇṇañca hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ, hiraññasuvaṇṇā vā. Sāli ca yavo ca sāliyavaṃ, sāliyavā
analyzed: dvande samāse assatthaḥ ca kapītanaḥ ca assattha kapītanam assattha kapītanā vā usīram ca  bīraṇam ca usīra bīraṇam usīra bīraṇāḥ vā ajaḥ ca eḷakaḥ ca ajeḷakam ajeḷakāḥ vā hiraññañca  suvaṇṇam ca hirañña suvaṇṇam hirañña suvaṇṇā vā sāli ca yavaḥ ca sāli yavam sāli yavā
translated: in a dvanda compound. And assattha and kapittha are assatthakapittha, or assatthakapitthā. And usīra🔽and vīraṇa are usīra vīraṇa, or usīra vīraṇā. And goat and ram are goat-and-ram, or goat-and-ram. And gold

original: vā. Kāsī ca kosalā ca kāsikosalaṃ, kāsikosalā vā.
analyzed: vā kāsī ca kosalā ca kāsi kosalam kāsi kosalāḥ vā
translated: and silver are gold-and-silver, or gold-and-silver. And rice and barley are rice-and-barley, or rice-and-barley. And Kāsi and Kosala are Kāsi-Kosala, or Kāsi-Kosalā.

original: Ādiggahaṇaṃ kimatthaṃ? Sāvajjañca anavajjañca sāvajjānavajjaṃ, sāvajjā navajjā vā. Hīnañca paṇītañca hīnapaṇītaṃ. Hīnapaṇītā vā. Kaṇho ca sukko ca kaṇhasukkaṃ, kaṇhasukkā vā.
analyzed: ādi gahaṇam kimattham sāvajjan ca anavajjan ca sāvajja anavajjam sāvajjāḥ navajjāḥ vā hīnam ca paṇītam ca hīna paṇītam hīna paṇītāḥ vā kaṇhaḥ ca sukkaḥ ca kaṇha sukkam kaṇha sukkāḥ vā
translated: What is the purpose of the initial statement? The reprehensible and the non-reprehensible are the reprehensible-and-non-reprehensible. The low and the refined are the low-and-refined. The black and the white are the black-and-white.

analyzed: dvipade tulya adhikaraṇe kammadhārayo
translated: , . In a compound with two words having the same case, the first is a kammadhāraya.

original: Dve padāni tulyādhikaraṇāni yadā samasyante, tadā so samāso kammadhārayasañño hoti.
analyzed: dve padāni tulya adhikaraṇāni yadā samasyante tadā saḥ samāsaḥ kammadhāraya sañño hoti
translated: When two words having the same case are compounded, that compound is called a kammadhāraya.

original: Mahanto ca so puriso cāti mahāpuriso, kaṇho ca so sappo cāti kaṇhasappo, nīlañca
analyzed: mahanto ca so puriso ca ati mahā puriso kaṇhaḥ ca so sappo ca ati kaṇha sappaḥ nīlañca
translated: A great man is a mahāpurisa. A black snake is a kaṇhasappo. A blue

original: taṃ uppalañcāti nīluppalaṃ, lohitañca taṃ candanañcāti lohitacandanaṃ, brāhmaṇī ca
analyzed: tam uppalam ca ati nīluppalam lohitam ca tam candanam ca ati lohitacandanam brāhmaṇī ca
translated: lotus is a nīluppala. Red sandalwood is lohitacandana. A brahmin

original: sā dārikā cāti brāhmaṇadārikā, khattiyā ca sā kaññā cāti khattiyakaññā.🔽Kammadhārayaiccanena kvattho? Kammadhārayasaññe ca.🔽325, 348. Saṅkhyāpubbo digu.
analyzed: sā dārikā ca ati brāhmaṇa dārikā khattiyā ca sā kaññā ca ati khattiya kaññā  kammadhāraya e canena kvatthaḥ kammadhāraya saññe ca  saṅkhyā pubbaḥ digu
translated: girl is a brāhmaṇadārikā. A khattiya maiden is a khattiyakaññā.🔽Why is the kammadhāraya called a kammadhāraya? Because it is desired as a kammadhāraya.

analyzed: saṅkhyā pubbaḥ kammadhāraya samāsaḥ digu saññaḥ hoti
translated: , . A compound with a numeral as its first member is a digu.🔽A compound with a numeral as its first member is called a digu.

original: Tīṇi malāni timalaṃ, tīṇi phalāni tiphalaṃ, tayo lokā tilokaṃ, tayo daṇḍā tidaṇḍaṃ, catasso disā catuddisaṃ, pañca indriyāni pañcindriyaṃ, satta godāvariyo sattagodāvaraṃ.
analyzed: tīṇi malāni ti malam tīṇi phalāni ti phalam tayaḥ lokā ti lokam tayaḥ daṇḍā ti daṇḍam catassaḥ disā catuddisam pañca indriyāni pañcindriyam satta godāvariyaḥ satta godāvaram
translated: The three stains is a timala, the three fruits is a tiphala, the three worlds is a tiloka, the three staffs is a tidaṇḍa, the four directions is a catuddisa, the five faculties is a pañcindriya, the seven Godāvarī rivers is a sattagodāvara.

analyzed: diguiccanena kvatthaḥ digusse kattam
translated: What is the Tappurisa? Digusse kattaṃ.

analyzed: ubhe tappurisā
translated: , . Ubhe tappurisā.

analyzed: ubhe digu kammadhāraya samāsā tappurisa saññā honti
translated: Both the Digu and the Ucchanta are called Tappurisa.

original: Na brāhmaṇo abrāhmaṇo, na vasalo avasalo, na bhikkhu abhikkhu, na pañcavassaṃ apañcavassaṃ,
analyzed: na brāhmaṇaḥ a brāhmaṇaḥ na vasalaḥ a vasalaḥ na bhikkhu a bhikkhu na pañcavassam a pañcavassam
translated: Not a brahmin is an abrāhmaṇa, not a low-caste person is an avasala, not a monk is an abhikkhu, not five years is an apañcavassa,

original: na pañcapūlī apañcapūlī, na sattagodāvaraṃasattagodāvaraṃ, na dasagavaṃ adasagavaṃ,
analyzed: na pañcapūlī a pañcapūlī na sattagodāvaram a sattagodāvaram na dasagavam a dasagavam
translated: not five pūlīs is an apañcapūlī, not seven Godāvarī rivers is an asattagodāvara, not ten cows is an adasagava,

analyzed: na pañcagavam a pañcagavam
translated: not five cows is an apañcagava.

analyzed: kvatthaḥ attam nassa tappurise
translated: What is the Tappurisa? Attaṃ nassa tappurise.

analyzed: am ādayaḥ para padebhiḥ
translated: , . Amādayo parapadebhi.

original: Tā amādayo nāmehi parapadebhi yadā samasyante, tadā so samāso tappurisasañño hoti.
analyzed: tāḥ ama ādayaḥ nāmehi para padebhi yadā samasyante tadā saḥ samāsaḥ tappurisa sañño hoti
translated: When those indeclinables called amādayo are compounded with other words, then that compound is called Tappurisa.

original: Bhūmiṃ gato bhūmigato, sabbarattiṃ sobhaṇo sabbarattisobhaṇo. Apāyaṃ gato apāyagato,
analyzed: bhūmim gataḥ bhūmi gataḥ sabbarattim sobhaṇaḥ sabbaratti sobhaṇaḥ apāyam gataḥ apāya gataḥ
translated: Beautiful for the whole night, is sabbarattiṃ sobhaṇo, sabbarattisobhaṇo.🔽Gone to the states of loss, is apāyaṃ gato, apāyagato.🔽Done by the lord, is issarena kataṃ, issarakataṃ.🔽Pierced by a dart, is sallaviddho.

original: issarena kataṃ issarakataṃ, sallena viddho sallaviddho, kathinassa dussaṃ kathinadussaṃ,
analyzed: issarena katam issara katam sallena viddhaḥ salla viddhaḥ kathinassa dussam kathina dussam
translated: The cloth of the hard, is kathinassa dussaṃ, kathinadussaṃ.🔽The meal for the visitor, is āgantukassa bhattaṃ, āgantukabhattaṃ.

original: āgantukassa bhattaṃ āgantukabhattaṃ, methunā apeto methunāpeto, corā bhayaṃ corabhayaṃ,
analyzed: āgantukassa bhattam āgantuka bhattam methunāḥ apetaḥ methuna apeto corāḥ bhayam cora bhayam
translated: Deprived of sexual intercourse, is methunāpetos.🔽Fear of thieves, is corabhayaṃ.🔽The king’s son, is rājaputto.🔽A heap of grain, is dhaññarāsi.🔽Perception of visible forms, is rūpasaññā.

original: rañño putto rājaputto, dhaññānaṃ rāsi dhaññarāsi, rūpe saññā rūpasaññā, saṃsāre dukkhaṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ.
analyzed: rañño puttaḥ rāja puttaḥ dhaññānam rāsi dhañña rāsi rūpe saññā rūpa saññā saṃsāre dukkham saṃsāra dukkham
translated: The suffering in the round of rebirths, is saṃsāradukkhaṃ.

analyzed: añña pada tthesu bahu bīhi
translated: In the sense of ‘other words’, a bahubbīhi compound is formed.

original: Aññesaṃ padānaṃ atthesu dve nāmāni bahūni nāmāni yadā samasyante, tadā so samāso bahubbīhi sañño hoti.
analyzed: aññesam padānam atthesu dve nāmāni bahūni nāmāni yadā samasyante tadā saḥ samāsaḥ bahu bīhi saññaḥ hoti
translated: When many names are compounded in the sense of other words, then that compound is called a bahubbīhi compound.

original: Āgatā samaṇā imaṃ saṅghārāmaṃ soyaṃ āgatasamaṇo, saṅghārāmo. Jitāni indriyāni anena
analyzed: āgatā samaṇāḥ imam saṅgha ārāmam saḥ ayam āgata samaṇaḥ saṅgha ārāmaḥ jitāni indriyāni anena
translated: The monks who have come to this monastery, is āgatasamaṇo, saṅghārāmo.🔽The monk who has conquered the faculties, is jitindriyo, samaṇo.

original: samaṇena soyaṃ jitindriyo, samaṇo. Dinno suṅko yassa rañño soyaṃ dinnasuṅko, rājā.
analyzed: samaṇena saḥ ayam jitindriyaḥ samaṇaḥ dinnaḥ suṅkaḥ yassa rañño saḥ ayam dinna suṅkaḥ rājā
translated: The king to whom the boon has been given, is dinnasuṅko, rājā.

original: Niggatā janā asmā gāmā soyaṃ niggatajano, gāmo. Chinno hatto yassa purisassa soyaṃ
analyzed: niggatāḥ janāḥ asmai gāmā saḥ ayam niggata janaḥ gāmaḥ chinnaḥ hattaḥ yassa purisassa saḥ ayam
translated: The man who has had his hand cut off, thus he is a handless man.

original: chinnahattho, puriso. Sampannāni sassāni yasmiṃ janapade soyaṃ sampannasasso, janapado.🔽Nigrodhassa parimaṇḍalo nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo, nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo iva parimaṇḍalo🔽yo rājakumāro soyaṃ nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo. Atha vā nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo iva parimaṇḍalo
analyzed: chinna hatthaḥ puriso sampannāni sassāni yasmin janapade saḥ ayam sampanna sassaḥ janapadaḥ  nigrodhassa parimaṇḍalaḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ iva parimaṇḍalaḥ  yaḥ rāja kumāraḥ saḥ iyam nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ atha vā nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ iva parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: The country in which the crops are good, thus it is a country with good crops.🔽The prince who is round like a banyan tree, thus he is a banyan-round prince. Or, he is a prince who is round like a banyan tree.

analyzed: yassa rāja kumārassa saḥ ayam nigrodhaparimaṇḍalaḥ rāja kumāraḥ
translated: The prince who is like a banyan-round prince, thus he is a banyan-round prince.

original: Cakkhuno bhūto cakkhubhūto, cakkhubhūto iva bhūto yo bhagavā soyaṃ cakkhubhūto, bhagavā.🔽Suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇo suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, suvaṇṇavaṇṇo viya vaṇṇo yassa bhagavato soyaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, bhagavā.
analyzed: cakkhunaḥ bhūto cakkhu bhūto cakkhu bhūtaḥ iva bhūtaḥ yaḥ bhagavā saḥ ayam cakkhu bhūtaḥ bhagavā  suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ viya vaṇṇaḥ yassa bhagavataḥ saḥ ayam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ bhagavā
translated: The Blessed One who is become the eye, thus he is the eye-become. The Blessed One who is become like the eye, thus he is the eye-become.🔽The Blessed One who has the colour of gold, thus he is the gold-coloured. The Blessed One who has a colour like gold, thus he is the gold-coloured.

original: Brahmuno saro brahmassaro, brahmassaro viya saro yassa bhagavato soyaṃ brahmassaro, bhagavā.
analyzed: brahmuno saraḥ brahmassaraḥ brahmassaraḥ viya saraḥ yassa bhagavataḥ saḥ ayam brahmassaraḥ bhagavā
translated: The Blessed One who has the voice of Brahmā, thus he is the Brahmā-voiced. The Blessed One who has a voice like Brahmā’s, thus he is the Brahmā-voiced.

original: Sayaṃ patita paṇṇa pupphaphalavāyutoyāhārāti paṇṇañca pupphañca phalañca paṇṇapupphaphalāni,
analyzed: sayam patita paṇṇa puppha phala vāyu toya āhārā ati paṇṇam ca puppham ca phalam ca paṇṇa puppha phalāni
translated: Food consisting of fallen leaves, flowers, fruits, and water: leaves and flowers and fruits are fallen leaves, flowers, and fruits;

original: sayameva patitāni sayaṃpatitāni, sayaṃpatitāni ca tāni paṇṇapupphaphalāni ceti sayaṃpatitapaṇṇapupphaphalāni
analyzed: sayam eva patitāni sayaṃpatitāni sayampatitāni ca tāni paṇṇa puppha phalāni ca iti sayam patita paṇṇa puppha phalāni
translated: they are fallen by themselves, thus they are fallen by themselves ; they are fallen by themselves and they are leaves, flowers, and fruits, thus they are fallen leaves, flowers, and fruits;

original: vāyu ca toyañca vāyutoyāni, sayaṃpatitapaṇṇapupphaphalāni ca vāyutoyāni ca sayaṃpatitapaṇṇapupphaphalavāyutoyāni.
analyzed: vāyu ca toyam ca vāyu toyāni sayaṃpatita paṇṇa puppha phalāni ca vāyu toyāni ca sayaṃpatita paṇṇa puppha phala vāyu toyāni
translated: air and water are air and water; they are fallen leaves, flowers, and fruits and they are air and water, thus they are fallen leaves, flowers, and fruits, air, and water;

analyzed: sayam patita paṇṇa puppha phala vāyu toyāni āhārāḥ yesam te sayam patita paṇṇa puppha phala vāyu toya āhārāḥ
translated: they have food consisting of fallen leaves, flowers, fruits, and water, thus they are those having food consisting of fallen leaves, flowers, fruits, and water;🔽the explanation of this should be given here as in the case of the former .

original: isayo. Yamettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Ayaṃ pana dvandakammadhārayagabbho🔽tulyādhikaraṇapahubbīhi.
analyzed: isayaḥ yam ettha vattabbam tam heṭṭhā vuttam eva ayam pana dvanda kammadhāraya gabbho  tulya adhikaraṇa pahup bīhi
translated: This is a dvanda compound with a bahubbīhi in apposition to it.

original: Atha vā – sayaṃpatitapaṇṇapupphaphalavāyutoyehi āhārā yesaṃ te sayaṃpatitapaṇṇapupphaphalavāyutoyāhārā. Ayaṃ pana bhinnādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.
analyzed: atha vā āhārāḥ yesam te sayam patita paṇṇa puppha phala vāyu toya āhārāḥ ayam pana bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: Or alternatively, they have food consisting of fallen leaves, flowers, fruits, and water, and air and water, thus they are those having food consisting of fallen leaves, flowers, fruits, and water; this is a bahubbīhi with a different headword .

original: Nānā dumapatita pupphavāsita sānūti nānāpakārā dumā nānādumā, nānādumehi patitāni🔽nānādumapati tāni, nānādumapatitāni ca tāni pupphāni ceti nānādumapatitapupphāni,
analyzed: nānā puppha vāsita nānā apakārāḥ dumāḥ nānā dumāḥ nānā dumehi patitāni  nānā duma pati tāni nānā duma patitāni ca tāni pupphāni ca iti nānā duma patita pupphāni
translated: And with slopes scented with flowers fallen from various trees: various trees are trees of various kinds, trees of many kinds. Flowers fallen from various trees are flowers fallen from those various trees.

original: nānādumapatitapupphehi vāsitā nānādumapatitapupphavāsitā, nānādumapatitapupphavāsitā🔽sānū yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu, pabbatarājā. Ayaṃ
analyzed: nānā duma patita pupphehi vāsitā nānā duma patita puppha vāsitā nānā duma patita puppha vāsitā  sānū yassa pabbatarājassa saḥ ayam nānā duma patita puppha vāsita sānu pabbatarājā ayam
translated: And those slopes are scented with those flowers fallen from various trees.🔽That king of mountains has slopes scented with flowers fallen from various trees.

original: pana kammadhārayatappurisagabbho tulyādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.🔽Atha vā – vāsitā sānū vāsitasānu, sāpekkhatte satipi gamakattā samāso. Nānādumapatitapupphehi
analyzed: pana kammadhāraya tappurisa gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi  atha vā vāsitā sānū vāsita sānu sāpekkha tte satipi gamaka ttā samāsaḥ nānā duma patita pupphehi
translated: But this is a compound with a co-relative in the form of a genitive-locative determinitive compound.🔽Or alternatively, the slopes are scented, thus they are scented slopes; though the dependence is there, there is a dvanda compound because of the meaning of ‘and’.

original: vāsitasānū yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu, pabbatarājā.
analyzed: vāsita sānū yassa pabbatarājassa saḥ ayam nānā duma patita puppha vāsita sānu pabbatarājā
translated: That king of mountains has slopes scented with flowers fallen from various trees.

analyzed: ayam pana bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bīhi
translated: This is a compound with a co-relative in the form of a determinitive compound with a different head word.

original: Byālambambudharabinducumbitakūṭoti ambuṃ dhāretīti ambudharo, ko so? Pajjunno. Vividhā
analyzed: ambum dhāreti iti ambudharaḥ
translated: And with its peaks kissed by the water-bearing moon’s orb: it bears water, thus it is water-bearing ; who is it? Pajjunna. Various

original: ālambo byālambo, byālambo ca so ambudharo cāti byālambambudharo, byālambambudharassa🔽bindū byālambambudharabindū, byālambambudharabindūhi cumbito byālambambudharabinducumbito,
analyzed: ālambaḥ byālambaḥ byālambaḥ ca saḥ ambudharaḥ ca ati byālamba mbudharaḥ byālamba mbudharassa  bindū cumbitaḥ
translated: is clinging, and he is the ocean, thus he is the clinging ocean,🔽the drops are the clinging ocean drops, and he is kissed by the clinging ocean drops, thus he is the one kissed by the clinging ocean drops,

original: byālambamburebinducumbito kūṭo yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ byālambambudharabinducumbitakūṭo.
analyzed: kūṭaḥ yassa pabbata rājassa saḥ ayam
translated: ‘Byālambambudharabindu’ is ‘byālambambudharo’ and ‘bindavo’ . ‘Byālambambudharabindūhi cumbito’ is ‘byālambambudharabindūhi’ and ‘cumbito’ . ‘Byālambambudharabindūhi cumbitakūṭo’ is ‘byālambambudharabindūhi’ and ‘cumbitakūṭo’ .

original: Ayaṃ pana kammadhārayatappurisagabbho tulyādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.🔽Atha vā – cumbito kūṭo cumbitakūṭo, sāpekkhatte satipi gamakattā samāso. Byālambambudharabindūhi
analyzed: ayam pana kammadhāraya tappurisa gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi  atha vā cumbitaḥ kūṭaḥ cumbita kūṭaḥ sa apekkha tte satipi gamaka ttā samāsaḥ
translated: This is a compound with co-ordinate terms in which the members are in apposition.

original: cumbitakūṭo yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ byālambambudharabinducumbitakūṭo. Ayaṃ pana
analyzed: cumbita kūṭaḥ yassa pabbatarājassa saḥ yam ayam pana
translated: Or alternatively, ‘cumbito kūṭo’ is ‘cumbitakūṭo’ . Although the expectation is for a genitive case, because of the fact that it is a compound, it is a dvanda compound. ‘Byālambambudharabindūhi cumbitakūṭo’ is ‘byālambambudharabindūhi’ and ‘cumbitakūṭo’ .

analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇa bahup bīhi
translated: This is a compound with co-ordinate terms in which the members are not in apposition.

original: Amita bala parakkamajutīti na mitā amitā, balañca parakkamo ca juti ca balaparakkamajutiyo,
analyzed: na mitāḥ amitāḥ bala parakkama jutīti na mitāḥ amitāḥ balam ca parakkamaḥ ca juti ca bala parakkama jutiyo
translated: ‘Amita bala parakkamajutī’ is ‘na mitā’ , ‘balañca parakkamo ca juti ca balaparakkamajutiyo’ ,

original: amitā balaparakkamajutiyo yassa soyaṃ amitabalaparakkamajuti, ayaṃ pana kammadhārayadvandagabbho
analyzed: amitāḥ bala parakkama jutiyaḥ yassa saḥ ayam amita bala parakkama juti ayam pana kammadhāraya dvanda gabbhaḥ
translated: This one has boundless strength, power, and speed. This is a compound of the dvandva type with a bahubbīhi ending.

analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇa bahup bīhi
translated: His shoulders and arms are well-rounded.

original: Pīṇorakkhaṃsa bāhūti uro ca akkhañca aṃso ca bāhu ca urakkhaṃsabāhavo, pīṇā urakkhaṃsabāhavo
analyzed: pīṇa urakkha aṃsa urakkha aṃsa urakkha aṃsa bāhu urakkha aṃsa bāhavaḥ pīṇāḥ urakkha aṃsa bāhavaḥ
translated: His chest, wrists, shoulders, and arms are well-rounded. His chest, wrists, shoulders, and arms are well-rounded.

original: yassa bhagavato soyaṃ pīṇorakkhaṃsabāhu. Ayaṃ pana dvandavabbho tulyādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.🔽Pīṇa gaṇḍa vadana thanūrujaghanāti gaṇḍo ca vadanañca thano ca ūru ca jaghanañca
analyzed: yassa bhagavataḥ saḥ uyam pīṇoḥ akkhaṃsa bāhu ayam pana dvanda vabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi  pīṇa gaṇḍa vadana thanu ūru jaghana ati gaṇḍau ca vadanam ca thanu ca ūru ca jaghanam ca
translated: The Blessed One has well-rounded shoulders and arms. This is a compound of the dvandva type with a bahubbīhi ending.🔽His shoulders, face, thighs, and hips are well-rounded.

original: gaṇḍavadanathanūrujaghanā, pīṇā gaṇḍavadanathanūrujaghanā yassā sāyaṃ pīṇagaṇḍavadanathanūrujaghanā.
analyzed: gaṇḍa vadana thanu ūru jaghanā pīṇā gaṇḍa vadana thanu ūru jaghanā yā sā sāyam pīṇa gaṇḍa vadana thanu ūru jaghanā
translated: His shoulders, face, thighs, and hips are well-rounded. His shoulders, face, thighs, and hips are well-rounded.

analyzed: ayam pi dvanda gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: This is also a compound of the dvandva type with a bahubbīhi ending.

original: Vavara surāsura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita selasaṅghaṭṭita
analyzed: sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita sela saṅghaṭṭita
translated: His head is bowed down by the crowns of the heads of the best of gods, demons, garuḍas, humans, snakes, gandhabbas, and mahoragas.

original: caraṇoti surā ca asurā ca garuḍā ca manujā ca bhujagā ca gandhabbā ca surāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbā,
analyzed: caraṇā iti surā ca asurā ca garuḍā ca manujā ca bhujagā ca gandhabbā ca sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabbā
translated: “Feet” means gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas. Gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas are gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas.

original: pavarā ca te surāsuragaruḍamanujabhujaga gandhabbā ceti pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbā,🔽pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbānaṃ makuṭāni pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbamakuṭāni,🔽pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbamakuṭānaṃ kūṭāni pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbamakuṭakūṭāni,🔽pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbamakuṭakūṭesu cumbitā pavarasurāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbamakuṭakūṭacumbitā,
analyzed: pavarā ca te sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabbā ca iti pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabbā  pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabbānam makuṭāni pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭāni  pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭānam kūṭāni pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭāni  pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭesu cumbitā pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbitā
translated: And those gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas are supreme. Gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas are supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas.🔽The crowns of those supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas are supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas’ crowns.🔽The peaks of those supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas’ crowns are supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas’ crowns’ peaks.

analyzed: pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbitā ca te selā ca ati pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita selā
translated: Those mountains kissed by the peaks of those supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas’ crowns are supreme gods, antigods, garuḍas, humans, nāgas, and gandhabbas’ crowns’ peaks-kissed mountains.

analyzed: saṅghaṭṭitā pavara sura asura  garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita sela saṅghaṭṭitā pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita sela saṅghaṭṭitā
translated: and the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities, which kiss the rock, are in contact with the rock, are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities, are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities,🔽are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities,

analyzed: caraṇāḥ yassa tathāgatassa saḥ ayam pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita sela saṅghaṭṭita caraṇaḥ
translated: the feet of which Tathāgata, this is the one whose feet are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities,

analyzed: tathāgataḥ ayam pana dvanda kammadhāraya tappurisa gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: the Tathāgata, but this is a person’s womb with a compound of two actions.

original: Atha vā–saṅghaṭṭitā caraṇā saṅghaṭṭitacaraṇā, sāpekkhatte satipi gamakattā samāso.🔽Pavarasurāsura garuḍamanujabhujaga gandhabbamakuṭakūṭacumbitaselehi saṅghaṭṭitacaraṇā
analyzed: atha vā a saṅghaṭṭitā caraṇā saṅghaṭṭita caraṇā sa apekkha tte satipi gamaka ttā samāsaḥ  saṅghaṭṭita caraṇā
translated: Or else: the feet are in contact, the feet which are in contact, although there is dependence, there is a compound because of the meaning of ‘to go’.

original: yassa tathāgatassa soyaṃ pavarasurāsuragaruḍa manujabhujaga gandhabbamakuṭakūṭacumbitaselasaṅghaṭṭita
analyzed: yassa tathāgatassa saḥ yam pavara sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabba makuṭa kūṭa cumbita sela saṅghaṭṭita
translated: The feet of which Tathāgata are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities, this is the one whose feet are in contact with the rock which kisses the peaks of the diadems of the excellent gods, Supaṇṇas, men, serpents and deities,

analyzed: caraṇaḥ ayam pana bhinna adhikaraṇa
translated: is the foot. But this is a bahubbīhi with a split base.

original: Catuddisoti catasso disā yassa soyaṃ catuddiso, bhagavā.
analyzed: catuddisā iti catassaḥ disāḥ yassa saḥ ayam catuddisaḥ bhagavā
translated: The four quarters: the four quarters are his, therefore he is the four-quarter one, the Blessed One.

original: Pañcacakkhūti pañca cakkhūni yassa tathāgatassa soyaṃ pañcacakkhu, tathāgato.
analyzed: pañca cakkhūni iti pañca cakkhūni yassa tathāgatassa saḥ ayam pañca cakkhu tathāgataḥ
translated: The five eyes: the five eyes are his, therefore he is the five-eyed one, the Tathāgata.

original: Dasabaloti dasa balāni yassa soyaṃ dasabalo, bhagavā.
analyzed: dasabalo ti dasa balāni yassa saḥ ayam dasa balaḥ bhagavā
translated: The ten powers: the ten powers are his, therefore he is the ten-powered one, the Blessed One.

original: Anantañāṇoti nassa anto anantaṃ, anantaṃ ñāṇaṃ yassa tathāgatassa soyaṃ anantañāṇo, tathāgato.
analyzed: ananta ñāṇo ti nassa antaḥ anantam anantam ñāṇam yassa tathāgatassa saḥ ayam ananta ñāṇo tathāgato
translated: The infinite knowledge: his knowledge is infinite, therefore he is the infinite-knower, the Tathāgata.

original: Amita ghana sarīroti na mitaṃ amitaṃ, ghanaṃ eva sarīraṃ ghanasarīraṃ, amitaṃ ghanasarīraṃ yassa tathāgatassa soyaṃ amitaghanasarīro, tathāgato.
analyzed: amita ghana sarīraḥ iti na mitam amitam ghanam eva sarīram ghana sarīram amitam ghana sarīram yassa tathāgatassa saḥ ayam amita ghana sarīraḥ tathāgataḥ
translated: The infinite-bulk body: his body is not measured, it is infinite, therefore he is the infinite-bulk-bodied one, the Tathāgata.

original: Amita bala parakkama pattoti na mitā amitā, balañca parakkamo ca balaparakkamā, amitā
analyzed: amita bala parakkama na mitāḥ amitāḥ balam ca parakkamaḥ ca bala parakkamāḥ amitā
translated: The infinite-strength-energy-attainer: his strength and energy are infinite, therefore he is the infinite-strength-energy-attainer,

original: eva balaparakkamā amitabalaparakkamā, amitabalaparakkamā pattā yena soyaṃ amitabalaparakkamapatto,
analyzed: eva bala parakkamā amita bala parakkamā amita bala parakkamā pattā yena saḥ ayam amita bala parakkama pattaḥ
translated: the infinite-strength-energy-attainer is he, therefore he is the infinite-strength-energy-attainer,

analyzed: bhagavā ayam pana tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: The Blessed One. But this is the womb of the construction of the case, the compound of the bahubbīhi type with a common base,

original: Matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasitapupphavallināgarukkho pasobhita kandaroti mattā
analyzed: matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkhaḥ mattā
translated: The mountain gorge adorned with creepers and flowering trees, the flowers of which are in bloom, kissed by swarms of bees.

original: eva bhamarā mattabhamarā, mattabhamarānaṃ gaṇā mattabhamaragaṇā, mattabhamaragaṇehi
analyzed: eva bhamarāḥ matta bhamarāḥ gaṇāḥ matta bhamara gaṇāḥ matta bhamara gaṇehi
translated: The bees are drunk, therefore they are called “drunk bees” (mattabhamarā). Swarms of drunk bees are called “swarms of drunk bees” (mattabhamaragaṇā).

original: cumbitāni mattabhamaraṇacumbitāni, vikasitāni eva pupphāni vikasitapupphāni, mattabhamaragaṇacumbitāni🔽vikasitapupphāni yesaṃ tehi mattabhamaragaṇacumbitavikasitapupphā, valli ca nāgarukkho🔽ca mallināgarukkhā, mattabhamaragaṇacumbitavikasitapupphā ca te vallināgarukkhā ceti
analyzed: cumbitāni matta bhamaraṇa cumbitāni vikasitāni eva pupphāni vikasita pupphāni matta bhamaragaṇa cumbitāni  vikasita pupphāni yesam tehi matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita pupphā ca nāgarukkhaḥ  ca malli nāga rukkhāḥ matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita pupphā ca te valli nāga rukkhāḥ ca iti
translated: The flowers are in bloom, therefore they are called “flowers in bloom” (vikasitapupphāni). The flowers in bloom that are kissed by swarms of drunk bees are called “flowers in bloom kissed by swarms of drunk bees” (mattabhamaragaṇacumbitavikasitapupphāni).🔽Those creepers and flowering trees are called “creepers and flowering trees” (vallināgarukkhā).

analyzed: matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkhāḥ matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkhehi
translated: Those creepers and flowering trees that are in bloom, kissed by swarms of drunk bees, are called “creepers and flowering trees” (mattabhamaragaṇacumbitavikasitapupphavallināgarukkhā).🔽The mountain gorge is adorned with those creepers and flowering trees.

analyzed: upasobhitāni matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkho
translated: beautified with flowering trees with clusters of flowers kissed by swarms of intoxicated bees, with flowering trees with clusters of flowers kissed by swarms of intoxicated bees,

original: pasobhitāni kandarāni yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ mattabhamaragaṇacumbitavikasitapuppha
analyzed: pasobhitāni kandarāni yassa pabbata rājassa saḥ yam matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha
translated: and beautified with trees of flowering creepers kissed by swarms of bees, and beautified with caves, of that King of Mountains this is the cave beautified with trees of flowering creepers kissed by swarms of bees,

original: vallināgarukkho paso bhitakandaro, pabbatarājā. Ayaṃ pana dvandakammadhārayatappurisagabbho🔽tulyādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.🔽Atha vā–upasobhitāni kandarāni upasobhitakandarāni, sāpekkhatte satipi gamakattā
analyzed: valli nāga rukkhaḥ pasaḥ bhita kandaraḥ pabbata rājā ayam pana dvanda kamma dhāraya tappurisa gabbho  tulya adhikaraṇa bahup bīhi  atha vā a upasobhitāni kandarāni upasobhita kandarāni sa apekkha tte sati pi gamaka ttā
translated: and the King of Mountains. This is a compound of two co-ordinated factors with a single verb.🔽Or alternatively: the caves are beautified, and they are beautified with trees of flowering creepers kissed by swarms of bees,

analyzed: samāsaḥ matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkhehi upasobhita kandarāni
translated: and they are beautified with trees of flowering creepers kissed by swarms of bees,

analyzed: yassa pabbata rājassa saḥ ayam matta bhamara gaṇa cumbita vikasita puppha valli nāga rukkhaḥ pasobhita kandaraḥ
translated: of that King of Mountains this is the cave beautified with trees of flowering creepers kissed by swarms of bees,

analyzed: pabbata rājā ayam pana bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: and the King of Mountains. This is a compound of two co-ordinated factors with separate verbs.

original: Nānā rukkha tiṇa patita pupphopasobhita kandaroti rukkho ca tiṇañca rukkhatiṇāni,
analyzed: nānā rukkha tiṇa patita puppha upasobhita kandara uti rukkhaḥ ca tiṇañca rukkhatiṇāni
translated: And the ravines are adorned with flowers fallen from various trees and grasses: the trees are the rukkha, and the grasses are the tiṇa,🔽and the various kinds of trees and grasses are the nānārukkhatiṇāni,

original: nānā pakārāni eva rukkhatiṇāni nānārukkhatiṇāni, nānārukkhatiṇehi patitāni nānārukkhatiṇapatitāni,🔽nānārukkhatiṇapatitāni ca tāni pupphāni ceti nānārukkhatiṇapatitapupphāni, nānārukkhatiṇapatitapupphehi
analyzed: nānā pakārāni eva rukkha tiṇāni nānā rukkha tiṇāni nānā rukkha tiṇehi patitāni nānā rukkha tiṇa patitāni  nānā rukkha tiṇa patitāni ca tāni pupphāni ca iti nānā rukkha tiṇa patita pupphāni nānā rukkha tiṇa patita pupphehi
translated: and the flowers fallen from the various trees and grasses are the nānārukkhatiṇapatitāni,

analyzed: upasobhitāni nānā rukkha tiṇa patita puppha upasobhitāni nānā rukkha tiṇa patita puppha upasobhitāni
translated: and the ravines are adorned with the flowers fallen from the various trees and grasses,

analyzed: kandarāni yassa pabbatarājassa saḥ ayam nānā rukkha tiṇa patita puppha upasobhita kandaraḥ
translated: and this is the mountain king’s ravines adorned with flowers fallen from various trees and grasses.

analyzed: pabbata rājā ayam pana dvanda kammadhāraya tappurisa gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: This is a dvanda compound and a taddhita compound.

original: Atha vā–upasobhitāni eva kandarāni upasobhitakandarāni, (sāpekkhatte satipi gamakattā
analyzed: atha vā a upasobhitāni eva kandarāni upasobhita kandarāni sa apekkha tte sati pi gamaka ttā
translated: Or alternatively, the ravines themselves are adorned, and so they are the upasobhitakandarāni, (although the word upasobhitakandarāni is a compound,🔽it is a dvanda compound, not a taddhita compound, because of the absence of the meaning of dependence.

original: samāso.) Nānārukkhatiṇapatitapupphehi upasobhitakandarāni yassa pabbatarājassa soyaṃ
analyzed: samāsaḥ nānā rukkha tiṇa patita pupphehi upasobhita kandarāni yassa pabbata rājassa saḥ oyam
translated: (Compound.) On the mountain-king, which is adorned with the flowers that have fallen from the various trees, creepers, and leaves,

original: nānārukkhatiṇapatitapupphopasobhitakandaro, pabbatarājā. Ayaṃ pana bhinnādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.🔽Nānā musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅgara sara dhanugadāsi tomarahatthāti musalo ca
analyzed: nānā rukkha tiṇa patita puppha upasobhita kandaraḥ pabbata rājā ayam pana bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi  ca
translated: this (mountain) has the caves adorned with the flowers that have fallen from the various trees, creepers, and leaves, (therefore it is called) the mountain-king. But this is a bahubbīhi with a different base.🔽With various pestles, ploughs, mountains, trees, bricks, lakes, bows, clubs, swords, spears, and hands,

original: phālo ca pabbato ca taru ca kaliṅgaro ca saro ca dhanu ca gadā caasi ca tomaro, ca🔽musalaphālapabbatatarukaliṅgarasaradhanugadāsitomarā, nānā pakārā eva musalaphālapabbatatarukaliṅgarasaradhanugadāsitomarā
analyzed: phālo ca pabbato ca taru ca kaliṅgaro ca saro ca dhanu ca gadā ca asi ca tomaro ca  musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅga rasara dhanu gadā asi tomarāḥ nānā pakārāḥ eva musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅga rasara dhanu gadā asi tomarāḥ
translated: the pestle and the plough and the mountain and the tree and the brick and the lake and the bow and the club and the sword and the spear,🔽the various pestles, ploughs, mountains, trees, bricks, lakes, bows, clubs, swords, and spears,

analyzed: nānā musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅga rasara dhanu gadā asi tomarā nānā musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅga rasara dhanu gadā asi tomarā
translated: the various pestles, ploughs, mountains, trees, bricks, lakes, bows, clubs, swords, and spears,

analyzed: hatthesu yesam te nānā musala phāla pabbata taru kaliṅgara sara dhanu gadā asi tomara hatthā
translated: those who have various pestles, ploughs, mountains, trees, bricks, lakes, bows, clubs, swords, and spears in their hands.

analyzed: ayam pana dvanda kammadhāraya gabbhaḥ bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi
translated: But this is a dvanda with a compound in the middle, and it is a bahubbīhi with a different subject.

analyzed: bahup bīhi i t canena kvatthaḥ bahup bīhimhi ca
translated: The kvatthu is by the desire for a bahubbīhi: and in a bahubbīhi.
A dvanda is a combination of nouns.

original: Nāmānaṃ ekavibhattikānaṃ yo samuccayo, so dvandasañño hoti.🔽Candimā ca sūriyo ca candimasūriyā, samaṇo ca brāhmaṇo ca samaṇabrāhmaṇā, sāriputto🔽ca moggallāno ca sāriputtamoggallānā, brāhmaṇo ca gahapatiko ca brāhmaṇagahapatikā,
analyzed: nāmānam eka vibhattikānam yaḥ samuccayaḥ saḥ dvanda saññaḥ hoti  candimā ca sūriyo ca candima sūriyā samaṇaḥ ca brāhmaṇaḥ ca samaṇa brāhmaṇā sāriputto  ca moggallāno ca sāriputta moggallānā brāhmaṇo ca gahapatiko ca brāhmaṇa gahapatikā
translated: A combination of nouns in the same case is called a dvanda.

original: yamo ca varuṇo ca yamavaruṇā, kuvero ca vāsavo ca kuveravāsavā.
analyzed: yamo ca varuṇo ca yama varuṇā kuvero ca vāsavo ca kuvera vāsavā
translated: The moon and the sun are candimasūriyā, the ascetic and the brahmin are samaṇabrāhmaṇā, Sāriputta and Moggallāna are sāriputtamoggallānā, the brahmin and the householder are brāhmaṇagahapatikā, Yama and Varuṇa are yamavaruṇā, Kuvera and Vāsava are kuveravāsavā.

analyzed: dvanda ai c canena kvatthaḥ dvandaṭṭhāḥ vā
translated: The kvatthu is by the desire for a dvanda: or in a dvanda-place.

analyzed: mahatam tulya adhikaraṇe pade
translated: A mahā is a great in a word with the same case-relation.

original: Tesaṃ mahantasaddānaṃ mahāādeso hoti tulyādhikaraṇe pade.
analyzed: tesam mahanta saddānam mahā ādesaḥ hoti tulya adhikaraṇe pade
translated: The mahā affix is made to those mahant-words in a word with the same case-relation.

original: Mahanto ca so puriso cāti mahāpuriso, mahantī ca sā devī cāti mahādevī, mahantañca
analyzed: mahantaḥ ca saḥ purisaḥ ca ati mahāpurisaḥ mahantī ca sā devī ca ati mahādevī mahantam ca
translated: He is great and a man, thus he is a great man ; she is great and a goddess, thus she is a great goddess ; it is great and a

original: taṃ balañcāti mahābalaṃ, mahanto ca so nāgo cāti mahānāgo, mahanto ca so yaso cāti🔽mahāyaso, mahantañca taṃ padumavanañcāti mahāpadumavanaṃ, mahantī ca sā nadī cāti
analyzed: tam balam ca ati mahābalam mahantaḥ ca saḥ nāgaḥ ca ati mahā nāgaḥ mahantaḥ ca saḥ yasaḥ ca ati  mahā yasaḥ mahantam ca tam paduma vanam ca ati mahā paduma vanam mahantī ca sā nadī ca ati
translated: It is a strength, thus it is a great strength. He is a great and a nāga, thus he is a great nāga. He is great and he is famous, thus he is greatly famous.

original: mahānadī, mahanto ca so maṇi cāti mahāmaṇi, mahanto ca so gahapatiko cāti mahāgahapatiko,
analyzed: mahā nadī mahantaḥ ca saḥ maṇi ca ati mahā maṇi mahantaḥ ca saḥ gahapatikaḥ ca ati mahā gahapatikaḥ
translated: It is a great and a lotus grove, thus it is a great lotus grove. It is a great and a river, thus it is a great river. It is a great and a gem, thus it is a great gem. He is a great and a householder, thus he is a great householder.

original: mahantañca taṃ dhanañcāti mahādhanaṃ, mahanto ca so puñño cāti mahāpuñño.
analyzed: mahantam ca tam dhanam ca ati mahādhanam mahantaḥ ca saḥ puñño ca ati mahā puññaḥ
translated: It is a great and a wealth, thus it is a great wealth. He is great and he is a merit, thus he is a great merit.

original: Bahuvacanaggahaṇena kvaci mahanta saddassa mahādeso hoti. Mahantañca taṃ phalañcāti mahapphalaṃ, mahabbalaṃ, evaṃ mahaddhanaṃ, mahabbhayaṃ.
analyzed: bahuvacana ggahaṇena kvaci mahanta saddassa mahādesaḥ hoti mahantam ca tam phalam ca ati mahat phalam mahat balam evam mahat dhanam mahat bhayam
translated: By the use of the plural, in some cases the word “great” has a great meaning. It is a great and a fruit, thus it is a great fruit. It is a great strength, thus it is a great wealth, a great fear.

analyzed: itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pum ava ce
translated: , . If a woman is spoken of by a man, the woman is to be seen as a man.

original: Itthiyaṃ tulyādhikaraṇe pade ce bhāsitapumitthī pumāva daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: itthiyam tulya adhikaraṇe pade ce bhāsita pumitthī pumā ava daṭṭhabbā
translated: If a word with a common base is spoken of by a woman, the woman is to be seen as a man.

original: Dīghā jaṅghā yassa soyaṃ dīghajaṅgho, kalyāṇabhariyo, pahūtapañño.
analyzed: dīghā jaṅghā yassa saḥ ayam dīgha jaṅghaḥ kalyāṇa bhariyaḥ pahūta pañño
translated: He has long shanks, thus he is this long-shanked one. He has a good wife, he has abundant wisdom.

original: Bhāsitapupeti kimatthaṃ? Brāhmaṇabandhu ca sā bhariyā cātibrāhmaṇabandhubhariyā.
analyzed: kimattham brāhmaṇa bandhu ca sā bhariyā ca ati brāhmaṇa bandhu bhariyā
translated: Why is the word bhāsita used? A wife who is a kinsman of a brahmin is a brahmin-kinsman-wife.

analyzed: kammadhāraya saññe ca
translated: In a compound with a feminine noun,

original: Kammadhārayasaññe ca samāse itthiyaṃ tulyādhikaraṇe pade pubbe bhāsitapumitthī ce, pumāva daṭṭhabbā. Brāhmaṇadārikā, khattiyakaññā, khattiyakumārikā.
analyzed: kammadhāraya saññe ca samāse itthiyam tulya adhikaraṇe pade pubbe bhāsita pumitthī ce pumā ava daṭṭhabbā brāhmaṇa dārikā khattiya kaññā khattiya kumārikā
