original: Bhujaiccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ anto no hoti, tapaccayassa ca dvitāvo hoti.🔽Bhutto, bhuttāvī, catto, satto, ratto, yutto, vivitto.
analyzed: dhātūnam antaḥ no hoti ta paccayassa ca dvitāvaḥ hoti  bhuttaḥ bhuttāvī cattaḥ sattaḥ rattaḥ yuttaḥ vivittaḥ
translated: The syllable gga is substituted for the syllable ta, when the syllable ta follows the root bhanj.

original: 579, 629. Vaca vāvu.🔽Vacaiccetassa dhātvassa vakārassa ukārādeso hoti anto cakāro no hoti, tapaccayassa ca dvebhāvo hoti vā.🔽Vuttaṃ bhagavatā, uttaṃ vā.🔽580, 630. Gupādīnañca.🔽Gupaiccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ anto ca byañjano no hoti, tapaccayassa ca dvebhāvo hoti.
analyzed: vaca vāvu 🔽va ca ai c ca itassa dhātvassa vakārassa ukāra ādesaḥ hoti antaḥ cakāraḥ no hoti ta paccayassa ca dvebhāvaḥ hoti vā 🔽vuttam bhagavatā uttam vā 🔽gupa ādi inañ ca 🔽dhātūnam antaḥ ca byañjanaḥ no hoti ta paccayassa ca dvebhāvaḥ hoti
translated: The syllable gga is substituted

original: Sugutto, catto, litto, santatto, utto, vivitto, sitto. Evamaññepi yojetabbā.
analyzed: su guttaḥ cattaḥ littaḥ santattaḥ uttaḥ vivittaḥ sittaḥ evam aññe pi yojetabbā
translated: well-guarded, gone, crossed, well-crossed, gone out, secluded, purified. So too in other instances.

analyzed: tara ādīhi iṇ ṇaḥ
translated: With tar and so on, the iṇ-form.

original: Taraiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tapaccayassa iṇṇādeso hoti, anto ca byañjano no hoti.
analyzed: tara e t ca evamādīhi dhātūhi ta paccayassa i ṇ ṇ ādesaḥ hoti antaḥ ca byañjanaḥ no hoti
translated: With the verbs beginning with tar, the iṇ-form of the past passive participle is formed from tap, and the vowel sign is not changed.

original: Taratīti tiṇṇo, uttaratīti uttiṇṇo, saṃpūratīti sampuṇṇo, turatīti tuṇṇo, parijīratīti parijiṇṇo, ākiratīti ākiṇṇo.
analyzed: tarati iti tiṇṇaḥ uttarati iti uttiṇṇaḥ saṃpūrati iti sampuṇṇaḥ turati iti tuṇṇaḥ parijīrati iti parijiṇṇaḥ ākirati iti ākiṇṇaḥ
translated: He has crossed = tiṇṇaṃ; he has gone out = uttiṇṇaṃ; he has filled = sampuṇṇaṃ; he has gone quickly = tuṇṇaṃ; he has worn out = parijiṇṇaṃ; he has heaped up = ākiṇṇaṃ.

analyzed: bhid āditaḥ inna annaḥ īṇ āvā
translated: With bhid and so on, the iṇ-form, the anna-form, and the īṇā-form.

original: Bhidiiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tapaccayassa inna anna īṇādesā honti vā, anto ca byañjano no hoti.
analyzed: bhidi id ca evamādīhi dhātūhi ta paccayassa i t na an ī ṇ ādesāḥ honti vā antaḥ ca byañjanaḥ no hoti
translated: With the verbs beginning with bhid, the iṇ-form, the anna-form, and the īṇā-form of the past passive participle are formed from tap, and the vowel sign is not changed.

original: Bhinditabboti bhinno, chindīyatīti chinno, ucchindīyitthāti ucchinno, dīyatīti dinno, nisīdatīti nisinno, suṭṭhu chādīyatīti suchanno, khidatīti khinno, rodatīti runno, khīṇā jāti.
analyzed: bhinditabbo ti bhinnaḥ chindīyati iti chinnaḥ ucchindīyittha ati ucchinnaḥ dīyati iti dinnaḥ nisīdati iti nisinnaḥ suṭṭhu chādīyati iti su channo khidati iti khinnaḥ rodati iti runnaḥ khīṇā jāti
translated: It should be split = bhinnaṃ; it should be cut = chinnaṃ; it should be cut off = ucchinnaṃ; it should be given = dinnaṃ; it should be sat down = nisinnaṃ; it should be well covered = suchannaṃ; it should be worn out = khinnaṃ; it should be wept = runnaṃ; khayaṃ jātiyaṃ = khayaṃ jātiyā.

analyzed: vāti kimattham bhijjati iti
translated: What is the purpose of the v? Bhidati = bhitti.

original: 583, 617. Susa paca sakato kkha kkā ca.
analyzed: su sa paca sa ka taḥ kkha kkā ca
translated: With sus, pac, sak, and so on, the kkha-form and the kkā-form.

original: Susa paca sakaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tapaccayassa kkhakkādesā honti, anto ca byañjano no hoti.
analyzed: su sa paca sa ka e c ca ivamādīhi dhātūhi ta paccayassa kkha kka ādesāḥ honti antaḥ ca byañjanaḥ no hoti
translated: The augment kkha is added to the root tap by the rules su, pac, saka, etc., and the vowel of the root is not lengthened.

original: Sussatīti sukkhaṃ, kaṭṭhaṃ, paccatīti pakkaṃ, phalaṃ. Sakati samattheti, pūjetīti vā sakko, sujampati.🔽584, 618. Pakkamādīhi nto ca.
analyzed: sussati iti sukkham kaṭṭham paccati iti pakkam phalam sakati samattheti pūjeti iti vā sakkaḥ sujampati  pakkama ādīhi ntaḥ ca
translated: Sukkhaṃ, kaṭṭhaṃ, pakkaṃ, phalaṃ. Sakko, sujampati.

original: Pakkamaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tapaccayassa ntoādeso hoti, anto ca no hoti.
analyzed: pakka ma e c ca evamādīhi dhātūhi ta paccayassa n ta ādesaḥ hoti antaḥ ca no hoti
translated: The augment nto is added to the root pak by the rules pakka, etc., and the vowel of the root is not lengthened.

original: Pakkamatīti pakkanto, vibbhamatīti vibbhanto, saṅkanto, khanto, santo, danto, vanto.🔽Caggahaṇaṃ kimatthaṃ? Teheva dhātūhi tapaccayassanti hoti. Anto ca no hoti. Kanti, khanti. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: pakkamati iti pakkantaḥ vibbhamati iti vibbhantaḥ saṅkantaḥ khantaḥ santaḥ dantaḥ vantaḥ  ca ggahaṇam kimattham tehi iva dhātūhi ta paccayassa anti hoti antaḥ ca no hoti kanti khanti evam sabbattha
translated: Pakkanto, vibbhanto, saṅkanto, khanto, santo, danto, vanto.

analyzed: jana ādi namā timhi ca
translated: What is the purpose of the statement of the exception? The augment kkha is added to the roots by the rules su, pac, saka, etc., and the vowel of the root is not lengthened. But the augment kkha is not added to the roots kanti, khanti.

original: Janaiccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ antassa byañjanassa āttaṃ hoti tapaccaye pare, timhi ca.
analyzed: jana e t ca evamādīnam dhātūnam antassa byañjanassa ā ttam hoti ta pad caye pare timhi ca
translated: The augment ā is added to the vowel of the root by the rules jana, etc., when the augment tap follows, and also in timhi.

analyzed: ajani iti jātaḥ jananam jāti
translated: Jāto, jāti.

original: Timhīti kimatthaṃ? Aññasmimpi paccaye pare ākāranivattanatthaṃ. Janitvā, janitā, janituṃ, janitabbaṃ iccevamādi.
analyzed: timhi iti kimattham aññasmin pi paccaye pare ākāra nivattana attham janitvā janitā janitum janitabbam icca evamādi
translated: Timhi: what is the purpose of this? In order to prevent the form of the other case-endings in the other conditions. Having generated, generator, to generate, to be generated.

analyzed: gama khana hana
translated: Gama, khana, hana, ram, etc.

original: Gama khana hana ramuiccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ anto byañjano no hoti vā tapaccaye pare timhi ca.
analyzed: gama khana hana ramu it ca evamādīnam dhātūnam antaḥ byañjanaḥ naḥ hoti vā ta paccaye pare timhi ca
translated: The vowel-sign of the verbal roots gama, khana, hana, ram, etc., is not optionally no in the following condition, and also in timhi.

original: Sundaraṃ nibbānaṃ gacchatīti sugato. Sundaraṃ nibbānaṃ gacchatīti sugati, khataṃ, khati. Upahataṃ, upahati. Rato, rati, mato, mati.
analyzed: sundaram nibbānam gacchati iti sugataḥ sundaram nibbānam gacchati iti sugati khatam khati upahatam upahati rataḥ rati mataḥ mati
translated: The beautiful Nibbāna is gone to, thus the well-gone . The beautiful Nibbāna is gone to, thus the good destination . It is broken, it breaks. It is struck, it strikes. It is delighted, delight. It is dead, it dies.

analyzed: vāti kimattham ramataḥ ramati
translated: Vati: what is the purpose of this? It delights, it delights in.

analyzed: rakāro ca
translated: Rakāro ca.

original: Rakāro ca dhātūnamantabhūto no hoti tapaccaye, pare timhi ca.
analyzed: rakāraḥ ca dhātūnam anta bhūtaḥ no hoti ta paccaye pare timhi ca
translated: The letter ra, which is the final letter of the verbal roots, is not optionally no in the following condition, and also in timhi.

original: Pakārena karīyatīti pakato, paṭhamaṃ karīyatīti pakati, visarīyatīti visato, visati.
analyzed: pakārena karīyati iti pakati visarīyati iti
translated: It is cooked by means of a pot, thus cooked . It is cooked first, thus natural . It is spread out, thus spread out . It spreads out.

analyzed: ṭhā pānami ī ca
translated: Ṭhāpānami ī ca.

original: Ṭhā pāiccetesaṃ dhātūnaṃ antassa ākārassa ikāra īkārādesā honti yathāsaṅkhyaṃ tapaccaye pare, timhi ca.
analyzed: dhātūnam antassa ākārassa ikāraḥ īkāra ādesāḥ honti yathāsaṅkhyam ta paccaye pare timhi ca
translated: The vowel-sign of the verbal roots ṭhā, pā, etc., is changed to i and ī respectively in the following condition, and also in timhi.

original: Yatra ṭhito, ṭhiti, pīto, pīti.🔽589, 621. Hantehi ho hassa ḷo vā adahanahānaṃ.
analyzed: yatra  hanta ihi ho hassa ḷaḥ vā a dahana hānam
translated: Wherein he stands, he stands in, he drinks, he drinks in.🔽The ḷ or ḷo is substituted for the final of the root in the sense of burning and heating.

original: Hakārantehi dhātūhi tapaccayassa hakārādeso hoti, hakārassa dhātvantassa ḷo hoti vā adahanahānaṃ.
analyzed: hakāra antehi dhātūhi ta paccayassa hakāra ādesaḥ hoti hakārassa dhātu antassa ḷaḥ hoti vā a dahana hānam
translated: The ḷ or ḷo is substituted for the final of the root in the sense of burning and heating.

analyzed: āruhittha iti āruḷhaḥ gāḷhaḥ bāḷhaḥ mūḷo
translated: He has mounted, he has climbed up, he is deep, he is thick, he is confused.

original: Adahanahānamiti kimatthaṃ? Dayhatīti daḍḍho, saṃsuṭṭhu nayhatīti sannaddho.
analyzed: a dahana hānam iti kimattham dayhati iti daḍḍhaḥ saṃsuṭṭhu nayhati iti sannaddhaḥ
translated: In the sense of not burning and not heating? He is burnt, he is well-cooked. He is harnessed, he is well-harnessed.

analyzed: iti kibbidhānakappe tatiyaḥ kaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter in the section on “How many kinds?”

analyzed: catuttha kaṇḍa  ṇam hi ran jassa jaḥ bhāva karaṇesu
translated: Chapter Four🔽The jo is substituted for the final njak of ranja in the sense of causing to be and causing to do.

original: Ṇamhi paccaye pare ranjaiccetassa dhātussa antabhūtassa njakārassa joādeso hoti bhāvakaraṇesu.🔽Rañjanaṃ rāgo, ranjanti etenāti rāgo.
analyzed: ṇamhi paccaye pare ra n ja e c e tassa dhātussa anta bhūtassa n jakārassa ja ādesaḥ hoti bhāva karaṇesu  rañjanam rāgaḥ ranjanti etena ati
translated: The jo is substituted for the final njak of the root ranja when the condition is in the locative case in the sense of causing to be and causing to do.🔽The causing of delight is delight, they delight by means of this, therefore it is delight.

analyzed: bhāva karaṇesu iti kimattham ranjati iti raṅgaḥ
translated: In the sense of causing to be and causing to do? The dye is delight.

analyzed: hanassa ghātaḥ
translated: The ghā is substituted for the final of the root hana in the sense of killing.

original: Hanaiccetassa dhātussa sabbassa ghātādeso hoti ṇamhi paccaye pare.
analyzed: hanai c ca itassa dhātussa sabbassa ghāta ādesaḥ hoti ṇamhi paccaye pare
translated: The ghā is substituted for the final of the root hana in the sense of killing when the condition is in the locative case.

analyzed: upahanati iti upaghātaḥ gāvaḥ hanati iti go ghātakaḥ
translated: He kills by approaching, therefore it is killing by approaching. He kills cows, therefore he is a cow-killer.

original: 592, 503. Vadho vā sabbattha.🔽Hanaiccetassa dhātussa vadhādeso hoti vā sabbattha ṭhānesu.
analyzed: vadhaḥ vā sabbattha  hanai c ca itassa dhātussa vadha ādesaḥ hoti vā sabbattha ṭhānesu
translated: The killing is in all places.

original: Hanatīti vadho, vadhako, avadhi, ahani vā.
analyzed: hanati iti vadhaḥ vadhakaḥ avadhi ahani vā
translated: He kills, thus he is a killer, a killer, or he has killed.

analyzed: ākāra antān amāyo
translated: The ending of the verbal roots.

original: Ākārantānaṃ dhātūnaṃ antassa ākārassa āyādeso hoti ṇamhi paccaye pare.
analyzed: ākāra antānam dhātūnam antassa ākārassa āya ādesaḥ hoti ṇamhi paccaye pare
translated: The ending of the verbal roots is āya in the case of the ending ṇam.

original: Dadātīti dāyako, dānaṃ dātuṃ sīlaṃ yassāti dānadāyī, majjaṃ dātuṃ sīlaṃ yassāti majjadāyī, nagaraṃ yātuṃ sīlaṃ yassāti nagarayāyī.
analyzed: dadāti iti dāyakaḥ dānam dātum sīlam yassa ati dāna dāyī majjam dātum sīlam yassa ati majja dāyī nagaram yātum sīlam yassa ati nagara yāyī
translated: He gives, thus he is a giver, a gift; he has the habit of giving, thus he is a giver of gifts; he has the habit of giving liquor, thus he is a giver of liquor; he has the habit of going to the city, thus he is a city-goer.

original: 594, 582. Pura samupa parīhi karotissa kha kharā vā tappaccayesuca.
analyzed: pura sam upa parīhi karoti kha kha rā vā tad paccayesu ca
translated: The kha and khara in the case of the verbal roots pura, sam, upa, pari, and karoti.

original: Pura saṃ upa pariiccetehi karotissa dhātussa kha kharādesā honti vā tapaccaye pare, ṇamhi ca.
analyzed: pura sam upa pari icca itehi karotissa dhātussa kha kha ra ādesāḥ honti vā ta paccaye pare ṇamhi ca
translated: The verbal roots pura, sam, upa, and pari, and the verbal root karoti have the endings kha and khara in the case of the ending ṇam, and also in the case of the ending tapaccaye.

original: Pure karīyatīti purakkhato, sammā karīyatīti saṅkhato, upagantvā karīyatīti upakkhato, parisamantato karotīti parikkhāro, saṃkarīyatīti saṅkhāro.
analyzed: pure karīyati iti purakkhataḥ sammā karīyati iti saṅkhataḥ upagantvā karīyati iti upakkhataḥ parisamantataḥ karoti iti parikkhāro saṃkarīyati iti saṅkhāro
translated: It is done in front, thus it is placed in front; it is done well, thus it is formed; it is done after approaching, thus it is approached; it is done all around, thus it is a requisite; it is done together, thus it is a formation.

original: Vāti kimatthaṃ? Upagantvā karotīti upakāro.🔽595, 637. Tave tunādīsu kā.
analyzed: vāti kimattham upagantvā karoti iti upakāraḥ  tave tuna ādīsu kā
translated: What is the purpose of the v? It is a help, because it goes and does.🔽In tave tuna, etc., the k is the substitute.

original: Tave tunaiccevamādīsu paccayesu karotissa dhātussa kāādeso hoti vā.
analyzed: tave tunā e c ca ivamādīsu paccayesu karotissa dhātussa kā ādesaḥ hoti vā
translated: In such instrumental cases as tave tuna, etc., the k is the substitute for the dhātu ending in o.

original: Kātave, kātuṃ, kattuṃ vā, kātuna, kattuna vā.🔽596, 551. Gama khana hanādīnaṃ tuṃ tabbādīsu na.
analyzed: kātave kātum kattum vā  gama khana hana ādīnam tum tap ba ādīsu na
translated: Kātave, kātuṃ, kattuṃ vā, kātuna, kattuna vā.🔽In gama, khana, hana, etc., the n is not so in tuṃ, tabba, etc.

original: Gama khana hanaiccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ antassa nakāro hoti vā tuṃ tabbādīsu paccayesu.
analyzed: gama khana hana e c ca evamādīnam dhātūnam antassa nakāraḥ hoti vā tum tabba ādīsu paccayesu
translated: In such instrumental cases as tuṃ, tabba, etc., the n is not the substitute for the dhātu ending in a in gama, khana, hana, etc.

original: Gantuṃ, gamituṃ, gantabbaṃ, gamitabbaṃ. Khantuṃ. Khanituṃ, khantabbaṃ, khanitabbaṃ. Hantuṃ, hanituṃ, hantabbaṃ. Hanitabbaṃ. Mantuṃ, manituṃ, mantabbaṃ, manitabbaṃ.
analyzed: gantum gamitum gantabbam gamitabbam khantum khanitum khantabbam khanitabbam hantum hanitum hantabbam hanitabbam mantum manitum mantabbam manitabbam
translated: Gantuṃ, gamituṃ, gantabbaṃ, gamitabbaṃ. Khantuṃ. Khanituṃ, khantabbaṃ, khanitabbaṃ. Hantuṃ, hanituṃ, hantabbaṃ. Hanitabbaṃ. Mantuṃ, manituṃ, mantabbaṃ, manitabbaṃ.

original: Ādiggahaṇaṃ kimatthaṃ? Tunaggahaṇatthaṃ. Gantuna, khantuna, hantuna, mantuna.🔽597, 641. Sabbehi tunādīnaṃ yo.
analyzed: ādi ggahaṇam kimattham gantuna khantuna hantuna mantuna  sabbehi tuna ādīnam yaḥ
translated: What is the purpose of the statement beginning with “tuṃ”? It is for the purpose of including “tuṃ”. Gantuna, khantuna, hantuna, mantuna.🔽In all, the y is the substitute for the tuṃ, etc.

original: Sabbehi dhātūhi tunādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ yakārādeso hoti vā.
analyzed: sabbehi dhātūhi tuna ādīnam paccayānam yakāra ādesaḥ hoti vā
translated: In all dhātus, the y is the substitute for the instrumental cases tuṃ, etc.

original: Abhivandiya, abhivanditvā, ohāya, ohitvā, upanīya, upanetvā, passiya, passitvā, uddissa, uddisitvā, ādāya, ādiyitvā.
analyzed: abhivandiya abhivanditvā ohāya ohitvā upanīya upanetvā passiya passitvā uddissa uddisitvā ādāya ādiyitvā
translated: Having worshipped, having worshipped, having left, having left, having brought near, having brought near, having seen, having seen, having pointed out, having pointed out, having taken, having taken.

analyzed: can antehi ra c cam
translated: With canantehi raccaṃ.

original: Cakāranakārantehi dhātūhi tunādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ raccādeso hoti vā.
analyzed: cakāra nakāra antehi dhātūhi tuna ādīnam paccayānam ra cca ādesaḥ hoti vā
translated: With the endings cakāra and nakāra, the vowel of the prepositions tun and so on becomes raccā.

analyzed: vivicca āhacca uhacca
translated: Having separated, having touched, having risen up.

analyzed: vāti kimattham hantvā
translated: What is the purpose of vati? Having killed.

analyzed: ca
translated: , . Disā svāna svāntalopo ca.

original: Disaiccetāya dhātuyā tunādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ svānasvādesā honti, antalopo ca.
analyzed: disa e c ca itāya dhātuyā tuna ādīnam paccayānam sva an sva ādesāḥ honti anta lopo ca
translated: With the preposition disā, the vowels of the prepositions tun and so on become svāna svā, and there is elision of the final.

analyzed: disvāna disvā
translated: Having seen, having seen.

original: 600, 645. Ma ha da bhehi mma yha jja bbha ddhā ca.
analyzed: ma ha da bhehi mma yha jja bbha ddhā ca
translated: , . Ma ha da bhehi mma yha jja bbha ddhā ca.

original: Ma ha da bha iccevamantehi dhātūhi tunādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ mma yha jja bbha ddhā ādesā honti vā antalopo ca.
analyzed: ma ha da bha iti ca ivam antehi dhātūhi tuna ādīnam paccayānam mma yha jja bbha ddhā ādesāḥ honti vā anta lopaḥ ca
translated: With the endings ma ha da bha and so on, the vowels of the prepositions tun and so on become mma yha jja bbha ddhā, and there is elision of the final.

original: Āgamma, āgamitvā, okkamma. Okkamitvā, paggayha, paggaṇhitvā, uppajja, uppajjitvā, ārabbha, ārabhitvā, āraddha, ārabhitvā.
analyzed: āgamma āgamitvā okkamma okkamitvā paggayha paggaṇhitvā uppajja uppajjitvā ārabbhaḥ ārabhitvā āraddhaḥ ārabhitvā
translated: Having come, having come, having stepped down, having stepped down, having risen up, having risen up, having arisen, having arisen, having begun, having begun, having begun, having begun.

original: 601, 334. Taddhitasamāsakitakā nāmaṃ vā’ tave tunādīsu ca.
analyzed: taddhita samāsa kitakāḥ nāmam vā tave tuna ādīsu ca
translated: And in the words ending in -tva, -tuna, etc., the name-base is either a compound or a derivative or a k-ta affix.

original: Taddhitasamāsakitakaiccevamantā saddānāmaṃva daṭṭhabbā tave tuna tvāna tvādipaccayante vajjetvā.
analyzed: taddhita samāsa kitaka e c ca ivam antā saddānām aṃva daṭṭhabbā tave tuna tvāna tva ādi paccaya nte vajjetvā
translated: The words ending in -tva, -tuna, -tvāna, etc., should be regarded as either a compound or a derivative or a k-ta affix, except in the case of the suffixes -tva, -tuna, -tvāna, etc.

analyzed: vāsiṭṭhaḥ pattadhammo kumbhakāraḥ icc evamādi
translated: Vasiṭṭha, pattadhamma, kumbhakāra.

analyzed: dumhi garu
translated: In dumhi, garu.

original: Dumhi akkhare yo pubbo akkharo, so garukova daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: dumhi akkhare yaḥ pubbaḥ akkharo saḥ garukaḥ iva daṭṭhabbaḥ
translated: The syllable that precedes the syllable dumh should be regarded as heavy.

analyzed: bhitvā chitvā datvā hutvā
translated: Bhitvā, chitvā, datvā, hutvā.

analyzed: dīghaḥ ca
translated: In dīgho ca.

analyzed: dīghaḥ ca saraḥ garukaḥ iva daṭṭhabbo
translated: The syllable that precedes the syllable dīgho should be regarded as heavy.

original: Āhāro, nadī, vadhū, te dhammā, opanayiko.
analyzed: āhāraḥ nadī vadhū te dhammā opanayiko
translated: Āhāro, nadī, vadhū, te dhammā, opanayiko.

analyzed: akkharehi kāra
translated: In akkharehi kāra.

original: Akkharatthehi akkharābhidheyyehi kārapaccayo hoti payoge sati.
analyzed: akkhara atthehi akkhara abhidheyyehi kāra paccayaḥ hoti payoge sati
translated: The instrumental case is the condition for the k-ta affix, when there is an effort.

original: A eva akāro, ā eva ākāro, ya eva yakāro.
analyzed: a eva akāraḥ ā eva ākāraḥ ya eva yakāraḥ
translated: A is the letter a, ā is the letter ā, ya is the letter ya.

analyzed: yathāgamam sabba dhātūhi sabba paccayesu ikāra āgamaḥ hoti
translated: The letter i is added to all the bases and all the conditions according to the order.

original: Kāriyaṃ, bhavitabbaṃ, janitabbaṃ, viditabbaṃ, karitvā, icchitaṃ.
analyzed: kāriyam bhavitabbam janitabbam viditabbam karitvā icchitam
translated: Kāriyaṃ, bhavitabbaṃ, janitabbaṃ, viditabbaṃ, karitvā, icchitaṃ.

analyzed: dadhantataḥ yaḥ kvaci
translated: In dadhantato yo kvaci.

original: Dakāradhakārantāya dhātuyā yathāgamaṃ yakārāgamo hoti kvaci tunādīsu paccayesu.
analyzed: dakāra dhakāra antāya dhātuyāḥ yathāgamam yakāra āgamaḥ hoti kvaci tuna ādīsu paccayesu
translated: The syllable ending in -ka, in the case of the root dhā, takes the augment -yak- according to the rule, in certain conditions beginning with the one beginning with -tu.

analyzed: buddhaḥ loke uppajjitvā dhammam bujjhitvā
translated: Having arisen in the world, the Buddha, having awakened to the Dhamma.

analyzed: kimattham labhitvā
translated: From the giving: what is the meaning of kimatthaṃ? Having obtained.

analyzed: kvaci iti kimattham uppādetvā
translated: In the case of kvacī: what is the meaning of kimatthaṃ? Having caused to arise.

analyzed: iti kibbidhānakappe catutthaḥ kaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth chapter in the section on the various ways of derivation.

analyzed: pañcama kaṇḍa  ro saṃyoga ādinaḥ
translated: Chapter Five🔽The nasal is used for the root saṃyoga and others.

analyzed: saṃyoga ādi bhūtaḥ nakāraḥ niggahitam āpajjate
translated: The nasal, which is the basis for the root saṃyoga and others, is used for the nasal.

original: Raṅgo, bhaṅgo, saṅgo.🔽608, 623. Sabbattha ge gī.
analyzed: raṅgo bhaṅgo saṅgo  sabbattha ge gī
translated: The stage, the breaking, the connection.🔽In all cases, ge becomes gī.

original: Geiccetassa dhātussa gīādeso hoti sabbattha ṭhāne.
analyzed: dhātussa gī ādesaḥ hoti sabbattha ṭhāne
translated: The stage ge of that root becomes the stage gī in all positions.

analyzed: gītam gāyati  sadassa sīdattam
translated: He sings a song.🔽The falling away of the existent.

original: Sadaiccetassa dhātussa sīdādeso hoti sabbattha ṭhāne.
analyzed: sa da e c ca itassa dhātussa sī t ādesaḥ hoti sabbattha ṭhāne
translated: The stage sīd of the root sada becomes the stage sīd in all positions.

analyzed: nisinnaḥ nisīdati  yajassa sarassi ṭṭhe
translated: He is seated, he sits down.🔽The pouring out of the sacrifice in the place of ṭṭhe.

original: Yajaiccetassa dhātussa sarassa ikārādeso hoti ṭṭhe pare.
analyzed: yaja e c ca itassa dhātussa sarassa ikāra ādesaḥ hoti ṭṭhe pare
translated: The stage ya of the root yaja becomes the stage sar in the place of ṭṭhe after.

analyzed: yiṭṭhaḥ yiṭṭhā
translated: The poured out, the poured out.

analyzed: ṭṭhā iti kimattham yajanam
translated: What is the meaning of ṭṭhe? The sacrifice.

analyzed: ha catutthānam antānam daḥ dhe
translated: The fourth case ending of the root ha becomes do.

original: Hacatutthānaṃ dhātvantānaṃ do ādeso hoti dhe pare.
analyzed: ha catutthānam dhātu antānam do ādesaḥ dhe pare
translated: The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is lengthened before a following vowel.

original: Sannaddho, kuddho, yuddho, siddho, laddho, āraddho.🔽612, 615. Ḍo ḍhakāre.
analyzed: sannaddhaḥ kuddhaḥ yuddhaḥ siddhaḥ laddhaḥ āraddhaḥ  ḍaḥ ḍhakāre
translated: Sanaddho, kuddho, yuddho, siddho, laddho, āraddho.

original: Hacatutthānaṃ dhātvantānaṃ ḍo ādeso hoti ḍhakāre pare.
analyzed: ha catutthānam dhātu antānam ḍaḥ ādesaḥ hoti ḍhakāre pare
translated: The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is lengthened before a following ḍhakāra.

analyzed: dayhati iti daḍḍhaḥ vaḍḍhati iti vuḍḍhaḥ
translated: Dayhati = daḍḍho, vaḍḍhati = vuḍḍho.

original: Ḍhakāreti kimatthaṃ? Dāho.🔽613, 583. Gahassa ghara ṇe vā.
analyzed: ḍhakāra iti kimattham dāhaḥ   gahassa ghara ṇe vā
translated: What is the purpose of the term ḍhakāra? Dāho.

original: Gahaiccetassa dhātussa sabbassa gharādeso hoti vā ṇapaccaye pare.
analyzed: gaha e c ca itassa dhātussa sabbassa ghara ādesaḥ hoti vā ṇa paccaye pare
translated: The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is lengthened before a following ṇapaccaye.

analyzed: gharam gharāni
translated: Gharaṃ, gharāni.

original: Vāti kimatthaṃ? Gāho.🔽614, 581. Dahassa do ḷaṃ.
analyzed: vāti kimattham gāho  dahassa daḥ ḷaṃ
translated: What is the purpose of the term vā? Gāho.

original: Dahaiccetassa dhātussa dakāro ḷattamāpajjate vā ṇapaccaye pare.
analyzed: daha e c ca itassa dhātussa dakāraḥ ḷ ttam āpajjate vā ṇa paccaye pare
translated: The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is lengthened before a following ḷapaccaye.

analyzed: paridahanam pariḷāhaḥ
translated: Paridahanaṃ = pariḷāho.

original: Vāti kimatthaṃ? Paridāho.🔽615, 586. Dhātvantassa lopo kvimhi.
analyzed: vāti kimattham paridāhaḥ  dhātu antassa lopaḥ kvimhi
translated: What is the purpose of the term vā? Paridāho.

original: Dhātvantassa byañjanassa lopo hoti kvimhi paccaye pare.
analyzed: dhātu antassa byañjanassa lopaḥ hoti kvimhi paccaye pare
translated: The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is dropped before a following kvimhi.🔽The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is dropped before a following kvimhi.

original: Bhujena gacchatīti, bhujago. Urena gacchatīti urago, turago, saṅkho.🔽616, 587. Vidante ū.
analyzed: bhujena gacchati iti bhujagaḥ urena gacchati iti uragaḥ turagaḥ saṅkho 🔽vidante ū
translated: Bhujena gacchatīti = bhujago, urena gacchatīti = urago, turago, saṅkho.🔽The vowel of the last syllable of the first three of the above is lengthened before a following ū.

original: Vidaiccetassa dhātussa ante ūkārāgamo hoti kvimhi paccaye pare.
analyzed: vida i t ca itassa dhātussa ante ūkāra āgamaḥ hoti kvimhi paccaye pare
translated: If the vowel of the base is a, the vowel u is added to the end of it, if the following syllable begins with k.

original: Lokaṃ vidati jānātīti lokavidū.🔽617, 633. Na ma ka rānamantānaṃ niyuttatamhi.
analyzed: lokam vidati jānāti iti  na ma ka
translated: He knows, penetrates, the world, therefore he is a lokavidū.🔽The elision of the final a of na, ma, ka, ra is not in niyuttatamhi.

original: Nakāra makāra kakāra rakārānaṃ dhātvantānaṃ lopo na hoti ikārayutte tapaccaye pare.
analyzed: nakāra makāra kakāra rakārānam dhātu antānam lopaḥ na hoti ikāra yutte ta paccaye pare
translated: The elision of the final a of na, ma, ka, ra is not in the following syllable if it begins with i, u, or t.

original: Hanibhuṃ, gamito, ramito, sakito, sarito, karitvā.
analyzed: hanibhum gamitaḥ ramitaḥ sakitaḥ saritaḥ karitvā
translated: Hanibhuṃ, gamito, ramito, sakito, sarito, karitvā.

original: Iyuttatamhīti kimatthaṃ? Gato, sato.🔽618, 571. Na ka gattaṃ ca jāṇvumhi.
analyzed: iyut tatamhi iti kimattham gataḥ sato  na ka gattam ca jāṇvumhi
translated: Why is it said “in niyuttatamhi”? Gata, sato.🔽The elision of ka, ga, ka, ga is not in ṇvumhi.

original: Cakāra jakārā kakāra gakārattaṃ nāpajjante ṇvumhi paccaye pare.
analyzed: cakāra jakārā kakāra gakāra ttam na āpajjante ṇ vumhi paccaye pare
translated: The elision of ka, ga, ka, ga is not in the following syllable if it begins with ṇ, v, or m.

analyzed: pacati iti pācakaḥ yajati iti yājakaḥ
translated: Pacatīti pācako, yajatīti yājako.

analyzed: karassa ca tad tam tusmin
translated: The elision of ra of kara is not in tusmiṃ.

original: Karaiccetassa dhātussa antassa rakārassa takārattaṃ hoti tupaccaye pare.
analyzed: ka ra i t ca itassa dhātussa antassa rakārassa takāra ttam hoti tu paccaye pare
translated: The elision of the final ra of the base kara is not in the following syllable if it begins with t.

analyzed: karoti iti kattā karonti iti kattāraḥ
translated: Karotīti kattā, karontīti kattāro.

analyzed: tum tuna tapbesu vā
translated: Tuṃ, tuna, tabba, or.

original: Karaiccetassa dhātussa antassa rakārassa takārattaṃ hoti vā tuṃ tuna tabbaiccetesu paccayesu.
analyzed: ka ra i t ca itassa dhātussa antassa rakārassa takāra ttam hoti vā tum tuna tap bai c ca etesu paccayesu
translated: The elision of the final ra of the base kara is not in the following syllable if it begins with tuṃ, tuna, or tabba.

original: Kattuṃ, kātuṃ, kattuna. Kātuna, kattabbaṃ, kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: kattum kātum kattuna kātuna kattabbam kātabbam
translated: Do, do, do. Do, should be done, should be done.

analyzed: kāritam viya ṇa anubandhaḥ
translated: Like done, without the suffix ṇ.

original: Ṇakārānubandho paccayo kāritaṃ viya daṭṭhabbo vā.
analyzed: ṇakāra anubandhaḥ paccayaḥ kāritam viya daṭṭhabbaḥ vā
translated: The suffix ṇ, the condition, should be seen like done.

original: Dāho, deho, vāho, bāho, cāgo, vāro, cāro, parikkhāro, dāyako, nāyako, lāvako, bhāvako, kārī, ghātī, dāyī.
analyzed: dāhaḥ dehaḥ vāhaḥ bāho cāgaḥ vāro cāro parikkhāraḥ dāyakaḥ nāyakaḥ lāvakaḥ bhāvakaḥ kārī ghātī dāyī
translated: Burning, body, carrying, arm, giving, turn, conduct, equipment, giver, leader, nourisher, nourisher, doer, killer, giver.

analyzed: vāti kimattham upakkharaḥ
translated: What is the purpose of vā? Upright.

analyzed: an a kā yu ṇu ūnam
translated: , . Not done, for the weak.

original: Yuṇvuiccetesaṃ paccayānaṃ ana akaiccete ādesā honti.
analyzed: yu ṇ vu it ca itesam paccayānam ana a ka e c ca ite ādesāḥ honti
translated: For the weak, these conditions, these replacements become not done.

analyzed: nandanam kārakaḥ
translated: Delightful, maker.

analyzed: ca
translated: , . Ka and gā for jāna.

original: Ca jaiccetesaṃ dhātvantānaṃ kakāragakārādesā honti ṇānubandhe paccaye pare.
analyzed: ca ja e c ca itesam dhātu antānam kakāra gakāra ādesāḥ honti ṇa anubandhe paccaye pare
translated: Ka and gā become the replacements for these final verbal bases in the condition ṇ, when the suffix ṇ is present.

analyzed: pākaḥ yogaḥ
translated: Cooking, yoga.

analyzed: iti kibbidhānakappe pañcamaḥ kaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth chapter in the section on the various ways of formation.

analyzed: kita kappaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ  uṇ ādi kappa
translated: The section on the various ways of formation is finished.🔽The section on the uṇ-prefix

analyzed: chaṭṭha kaṇḍa
translated: Sixth chapter

analyzed: kattari kita
translated: , . Kita in the causative.

analyzed: atthe k ita paccayāḥ honti
translated: Kita become the conditions in the sense of the causative.

original: Kāru, kāruko, kārako, pācako, kattā, janitā, pacitā, netā.
analyzed: kāru kāruko kārako pācako kattā janitā pacitā netā
translated: Carver, carver, maker, cooker, doer, producer, cooker, leader.

analyzed: bhāva kammesu khatthā
translated: In verbs of becoming, the instrumental is the function.

original: Bhāvakammaiccetesvatthesu kicca tta khatthaiccete paccayā honti.
analyzed: bhāva kamma ai c ca ite su atthesu kicca tta khattha ai c ca ete paccayāḥ honti
translated: In these meanings, namely, in verbs of becoming, these conditions are the instrumental:

original: Upasampādetabbaṃ upasampādanīyaṃ bhavatā, sayitabbaṃ bhavatā, kattabbaṃ bhavatā,🔽bhottabbo odano bhavatā, asitabbaṃ bhojanaṃ bhavatā, asitaṃ bhavatā, sayitaṃ bhavatā,🔽pacitaṃ bhavatā, asitaṃ asanaṃ bhavatā, sayitaṃ sayanaṃ bhavatā, pacito odano bhavatā,
analyzed: upasampādetabbam upasampādanīyam bhavatā sayitabbam bhavatā kattabbam bhavatā  bhottabbaḥ odanaḥ bhavatā asitabbam bhojanam bhavatā asitam bhavatā sayitam bhavatā  pacitam bhavata asitam asanam bhavata sayitam sayanam bhavata pacitaḥ odanaḥ bhavata
translated: “You should be ordained,” “You should sleep,” “You should do,”🔽“You should eat rice,” “You should eat food,” “You have eaten,” “You have slept,”🔽“You have cooked,” “You have eaten a meal,” “You have slept on a bed,” “You have cooked rice,”

analyzed: bhavatā
translated: “You should do something,” “You should do this,” “You should do that,” “You should do well.”

analyzed: kammani dutiyāya ttaḥ
translated: In verbs, the second case is the agent.

original: Kammani iccetasmiṃ atthe dutiyāyaṃ vibhattiyaṃ kattari ttapaccayo hoti.
analyzed: kammani iti ca itasmin atthe dutiyāyam vibhattiyam kattari tta paccayaḥ hoti
translated: In this meaning, namely, in verbs, the second case is the instrumental case.

original: Dānaṃ dinno devadatto, sīlaṃ rakkhito devadatto, bhattaṃ bhutto devadatto, garuṃ upāsito devadatto.
analyzed: dānam dinnaḥ devadattaḥ sīlam rakkhitaḥ devadattaḥ bhattam bhuttaḥ devadattaḥ garum upāsitaḥ devadattaḥ
translated: “Devadatta has given a gift,” “Devadatta has guarded virtue,” “Devadatta has eaten food,” “Devadatta has served his elders.”

original: 627, 652. Khyādīhi māna ma ca to vā.
analyzed: khyā dīhi māna ma ca taḥ vā
translated: In the words beginning with ‘khyā,’ the instrumental is the object, or the second case is the object.

original: Khi bhī su ru hu vā dhū hi lū pī adaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi mana paccayo hoti, massa ca to hoti vā.
analyzed: khi bhī su ru hu vā dhū hi lū pī a dai c ca evamādīhi dhātūhi mana paccayaḥ hoti massa ca to hoti vā
translated: The mind is a condition for the roots of unprofit beginning with greed, and for the words of the same kind beginning with “khe” and “bhe” and “som” and “rom” and “hom” and “vā” and “dhū” and “lū” and “pī” and “ada”.

original: Khīyanti upaddavā etthāti khemo, bhāyitabboti bhemo, bhāyanti etasmāti vā bhemo,
analyzed: khīyanti upaddavāḥ ettha ati khemaḥ bhāyitabbo ti bhemaḥ bhāyanti etasmā ati vā bhemaḥ
translated: “Khe” is a place where calamities are destroyed; “bhe” is what should be feared, or it is from which one fears;

original: raṃsiyo abhissavetīti somo, ravati gacchatīti romo, huvati juhvati etenāti homo,
analyzed: raṃsiyaḥ abhissaveti iti somaḥ ravati gacchati iti romaḥ huvati juhvati etena ati homaḥ
translated: “som” is what shines and rains; “rom” is what goes and roars; “hom” is what goes and burns;

original: paṭilomavasena vāti gacchatīti vāmo, lāmakavasena vāti gacchati pavattatīti vā vāmo,🔽dhunāti kampatīti dhūmo, seṭṭhabhāvena hinoti pavattati cittaṃ etasminti hemo, lunitabboti
analyzed: paṭiloma vasena vāti gacchati iti vāmaḥ lāmaka vasena vāti gacchati pavattati iti vā vāmaḥ  dhunāti kampati iti dhūmaḥ seṭṭha bhāvena hinoti pavattati cittam etasmin ti hemaḥ lunitabbo ti
translated: “vā” is what goes in the opposite direction, or what goes and occurs in a crooked way;

original: lomo, maṃsacammāni lunāti chindatīti vā lomo, piyanaṃ pemo, piyāyitabboti vā pemo,
analyzed: lomaḥ maṃsa cammāni lunāti chindati iti vā lomaḥ piyanam pemaḥ piyāyitabbo ti vā pemaḥ
translated: “dhū” is what shakes and smokes; “hemo” is what the mind goes and occurs in as the best; “lomo” is what should be shaved, or what shaves and cuts flesh and skin; “pemo” is what should be loved, or what is loved;

original: sukhadukkhaṃ adati bhakkhatīti attā, jātijarāmaraṇādīhi adīyate bhakkhīyateti vā attā, ātumā.
analyzed: sukha dukkham adati bhakkhati iti attā jāti jarā maraṇa ādīhi a dīyate bhakkhīyate iti vā attā ātumā
translated: “attā” is what takes and eats pleasure and pain, or what is taken and eaten by birth, ageing, death, etc.; “ātumā” is a heap.

analyzed: samādīhi tha mā
translated: “Tha” is a condition for “mā”.

original: Samu damu dara raha du hi si bhī dā yā sā ṭhābhasaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tha ma paccayā honti.🔽Sametīti samatho, damatīti damatho, damanaṃ vā damatho, damitabboti vā damatho, daratīti🔽daratho, jiṇṇabhāvaṃ rahissati gaṇhissatīti ratho, dabbasambhāre rahati gaṇhātīti🔽vā ratho, davati gacchatīti dumo, davati vuddhi viruḷhi gacchati pavattatīti uddhaṃ🔽vā dumo, pathavīpabbatādīsu gacchati patatīti himo, kammavācāya bandhati etthāti
analyzed: samu damu dara raha du hi si bhī dā yā sā ṭha abha sai c ca ivamādīhi dhātūhi tha ma paccayāḥ honti  sameti iti samathaḥ damati iti damathaḥ damanam vā damathaḥ damitabbaḥ iti vā damathaḥ darati iti  darathaḥ jiṇṇa bhāvam rahissati gaṇhissati iti rathaḥ dabba sambhāre rahati gaṇhāti iti  vā rathaḥ davati gacchati iti dumaḥ davati gacchati pavattati iti  vā dumaḥ pathavī pabbata ādīsu gacchati patati iti himaḥ kamma vācāya bandhati ettha ati
translated: The suffixes tha, ma, paccaya are used after the roots samu, damu, dara, raha, du, hi, si, bhī, dā, yā, sā, ṭhā, bhasa.

original: sīmā. Bandhitabbāti vā sīmā. Bhāyanti etasmāti bhīmo, satte avakhaṇḍenti nivārenti🔽etenāti dāmo, mūsikādīhi khādīyati avakhaṇḍīyatīti vā dāmo, yāti gacchatīti yāmo,🔽paresaṃ cittaṃ gaṇhituṃ samatthetīti sāmo, tiṭṭhanti etenāti thāmo, bhasati bhasmīkarīyatīti bhasmā.
analyzed: sīmā bandhitabbā ati vā sīmā bhāyanti etasmā ati satte avakhaṇḍenti nivārenti 🔽etena ati dāmaḥ mūsika ādīhi khādīyati avakhaṇḍīyati iti vā dāmaḥ yāti gacchati iti yāmaḥ 🔽paresam cittam gaṇhitum samattheti iti sāmaḥ tiṭṭhanti etena ati thāmaḥ bhasati bhasmīkarīyati iti bhasmā
translated: Samathati = samatho. Damathati = damatho. Or: that which is to be subdued is damatho. Darathati = daratho. It will take to itself the state of being worn out = ratho. Or: it takes to itself the equipment of speed = ratho. Davati = dumo. It goes, it grows, it increases, it occurs = uddhaṃ dumo. It goes, it falls, on the earth, on a rock, etc. = himo. It is bound by the word of action = sīmā. Or: it is to be bound = sīmā. They fear it = bhīmo. It cuts off, it prevents, beings = dāmo. Or: it is not cut off, it is not destroyed, by mice, etc. = dāmo. It goes = yāmo. It is able to take the minds of others = sāmo. They stand by it = thāmo. It is burnt, it is reduced to ashes = bhasmā.

original: 629, 569. Gahassu’padhasse vā.🔽Gahaiccetassa dhātussa upadhassa akārassa etta hoti vā.
analyzed: gahassa upadhasse vā  gaha ai c ca itassa dhātussa upadhassa akārassa e t ta hoti vā
translated: In gaha and upadhā,🔽In gaha and in upadhā, etta is the vowel of the base.

analyzed: dabba sambhāra gaṇhāti iti geham gaham
translated: He takes (gaṇhāti) a house (gaha) for himself (icceta), thus it is a house (geha).

analyzed: masussa sussa cchara ccherā
translated: In masu, sussa, cchara, ccherā.

analyzed: ma su it ca itassa pāṭipadikassa sussa ccha ra ccheḥ ādesāḥ honti
translated: In masu, the vowel of the base is sussa, cchara, ccherā.

analyzed: mat śarati iti maccharaḥ evam maccheraḥ
translated: He is jealous (maccharati), thus he is jealous (macchara), thus he is jealous (evaṃ macchero).

analyzed: ā pubba carassa ca
translated: In āpubbacara, and.

original: Āpubbassa caraiccetassa dhātussa cchariyaccharaccherā desā honti, āpubbassa ca rasso hoti.
analyzed: āpubbassa caraiccetassa dhātussa cchariya chara cherāḥ desāḥ honti āpubbassa ca rassaḥ hoti
translated: In āpubba, the vowel of the base is cchari, cchara, ccherā, and āpubba is short.

original: Ābhuso caritabbanti acchariyaṃ. Evaṃ accharaṃ, accheraṃ.
analyzed: ābhuso caritabbanti acchariyam evam accharam accheram
translated: It should be gone (caritabbam) to by many, thus it is a wonder (acchariyaṃ), thus it is a wonder (evaṃ accharaṃ, accheraṃ).

original: Caggahaṇena masussa sussāpi cchariyādeso hoti, macchariyaṃ.
analyzed: ca ggahaṇena ma sussa sussa api cchariya ādesaḥ hoti macchariyam
translated: By the mention of cchara, in masu, sussa is also cchari.

analyzed: ala kala salehi layā
translated: In ala, kala, sala, la is added.

original: Ala kala salaiccetehi dhātūhi la yapaccayā honti.
analyzed: ala kala sala icca itehi dhātūhi la ya paccayāḥ honti
translated: In ala, kala, sala, la is added as a suffix.

original: Alati samatthetīti allaṃ, kalitabbaṃ saṅkhyātabbanti kallaṃ, salati gacchati pavisatīti sallaṃ. Evaṃ alyaṃ, kalyaṃ, salyaṃ.
analyzed: alati samattheti iti allam kalitabbam saṅkhyātabbam iti kallam salati gacchati pavisati iti sallam evam alyam kalyam salyam
translated: He is wet (alati) by the water, thus he is wet (allaṃ), it should be counted (kalitabbaṃ) by the number, thus it is proper (kallaṃ), it is spread (salati) and goes and enters, thus it is a dart (sallaṃ), thus it is wet (evaṃ alyaṃ), thus it is proper (kalyaṃ), thus it is a dart (salyaṃ).

analyzed: yāṇa lāṇā
translated: Yāṇa, lāṇā.

original: Tehi kala salaiccetehi dhātūhi yāṇa lāṇapaccayā honti.
analyzed: tehi kala salaicca itehi dhātūhi yāṇa lāṇa paccayāḥ honti
translated: They are the conditions for yāṇa and lāṇā by the method of analysis.

original: Kalitabbaṃ saṅkhyātabbanti kalyāṇaṃ, gaṇato paṭikkamitvā salanti etthāti paṭisalyāṇaṃ. Evaṃ sallāṇo, paṭisallāṇo.
analyzed: kalitabbam saṅkhyātabbam ti kalyāṇam gaṇataḥ paṭikkamitvā salanti ettha ati paṭisalyāṇam evam sallāṇaḥ paṭisallāṇaḥ
translated: What is to be reckoned as good is kalyāṇa; what is reckoned from the group is salanti ettha = paṭisalyāṇa; thus sallāṇo, paṭisallāṇo.

original: 634, 658. Mathissa thassa lo ca.🔽Mathaiccetassa dhātussa thassa lādesohoti. Aññamaññaṃ mathati viloḷatīti mallo, mallaṃ.
analyzed: mathissa thassa lo ca  matha e c ca itassa dhātussa thassa la ādesaḥ ho ti aññam aññam mathati viloḷati iti mallaḥ mallam
translated: Mathissa thassa lo ca.🔽The lo affix is added to the base mathicceta, and the th affix is added to that; thus mallo, mallaṃ.

original: Caggahaṇena lato ko ca āgamo hoti. Mallako, mallakaṃ.
analyzed: ca ggahaṇena la taḥ kaḥ ca āgamaḥ hoti mallakaḥ mallakam
translated: By the rule of the first class, the lo affix is added to the base mathicceta, and the ka affix is added to that; thus mallako, mallakaṃ.

analyzed: pesa atisagga patta kāla isu kiccā
translated: Pesātisaggapattakālesukiccā.

analyzed: pesa atisagga patta kāla aicca itesu atthesu kicca paccayāḥ honti
translated: The pes, atisagga, patta, kāla, and icc affixes are added as conditions for the meaning of action in these instances.

original: Kattabbaṃ kammaṃ bhavatā, karaṇīyaṃ kiccaṃ bhavatā, bhottabbaṃ bhojanaṃ bhavatā, bhojanīyaṃ bhojanaṃ bhavatā, ajjhayitabbaṃ ajjheyyaṃ bhavatā, ajjhayanīyaṃ ajjheyyaṃ bhavatā.
analyzed: kattabbam kammam bhavatā karaṇīyam kiccam bhavatā bhottabbam bhojanam bhavatā bhojanīyam bhojanam bhavatā ajjhayitabbam ajjheyyam bhavatā ajjhayanīyam ajjheyyam bhavatā
translated: The action that is to be done by you is kattabbaṃ kammaṃ bhavatā; the action that is to be done by you is karaṇīyaṃ kiccaṃ bhavatā; the food that is to be eaten by you is bhottabbaṃ bhojanaṃ bhavatā; the food that is to be eaten by you is bhojanīyaṃ bhojanaṃ bhavatā; the bride that is to be married by you is ajjhayitabbaṃ ajjheyyaṃ bhavatā; the bride that is to be married by you is ajjhayanīyaṃ ajjheyyaṃ bhavatā.

analyzed: avassaka adhamiṇesu ṇī ca
translated: Avassakā’dhamiṇesu ṇī ca.

original: Avassaka adhamiṇaiccetesvatthesu ṇīpaccayo hoti, kiccā ca.🔽Avassate tāva – kārīsi me kammaṃ avassaṃ hārīsi me bhāraṃ avassaṃ.🔽Adhamiṇe – dāyīsi me sataṃ iṇaṃ, dhārīsi me sahassaṃ iṇaṃ.🔽Kiccā ca – dātabbaṃ me bhavatā sataṃ iṇaṃ. Dhārayitabbaṃ me bhavatā sahassaṃ iṇaṃ, kattabbaṃ me bhavatā gehaṃ, karaṇīyaṃ me bhavatā kiccaṃ, kāriyaṃ me bhavatā sayanaṃ.🔽637, 0. Arahasakkādīhi tuṃ.🔽Araha sakka bhabbaiccevamādīhi payoge sati sabbadhātūhi tuṃpaccayo hoti.
analyzed: a vassaka a dhami ṇa e c ca i te su atthesu ṇī paccayaḥ hoti k itcā ca  avassate tāva kārīsi me kammam avassam hārīsi me bhāram avassam  adhamiṇe dāyīsi me satam iṇam dhārīsi me sahassam iṇam  kiccā ca dātabbam me bhavatā satam iṇam dhārayitabbam me bhavatā sahassam iṇam kattabbam me bhavatā geham karaṇīyam me bhavatā kiccam kāriyam me bhavatā sayanam  a rahasakka ādīhi tum  araha sakka bhabba ecca evamādīhi payoge sati sabba dhātūhi tum paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The suffixes -ā and -ā are used in the sense of ‘to be done’ and ‘to be owed’, respectively.🔽First, in the sense of ‘to be done’: ‘Do my work for me, please’, ‘Carry my load for me, please’.🔽In the sense of ‘to be owed’: ‘Pay me a hundred, please’, ‘Pay me a thousand, please’.🔽And in the sense of ‘to be done’: ‘You should pay me a hundred, please’, ‘You should pay me a thousand, please’, ‘You should build me a house, please’, ‘You should do my work, please’, ‘You should make me a bed, please’.🔽But -ā and -ā are used with araha, sakka, bhava, and so on.🔽When the words araha, sakka, bhava, and so on are used in the sense of ‘able’, the suffix -ā is used with all noun-bases.

original: Arahā bhavaṃ vattuṃ, arahā bhavaṃ kattuṃ, sakkā bhavaṃ hantuṃ, sakkā bhavaṃ janetuṃ, janituṃ, bhavituṃ, sakkā bhavaṃ dātuṃ, sakkā bhavaṃ gantuṃ, tabbo bhavaṃ janetuṃ iccevamādi.🔽638, 660. Vajādīhipabbajjādayo nippajjante.
analyzed: arahā bhavam vattum arahā bhavam kattum sakkā bhavam hantum sakkā bhavam janetum janitum bhavitum sakkā bhavam dātum sakkā bhavam gantum tabbaḥ bhavam janetum icca evamādi 🔽vaja ādi ihi pabbajja ādayaḥ nippajjante

original: Vajaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi, upasaggapaccayādīhi ca pabbajjādayo saddā nippajjante.🔽Paṭhamameva vajitabbāti pabbajjā, iñjanaṃ ejjā, samajjanaṃ samajjā, nisīdanaṃ nisajjā,🔽vijānanaṃ vijjā visajjanaṃ visajjā, padanaṃ pajjā, hananaṃ vajjhā, esanaṃ icchā,🔽atiesanaṃ aticchā, sadanaṃ sajjā, sayanti etthāti seyyā, sammā cittaṃ nidheti etāyāti
analyzed: vaja e t ca evamādīhi dhātūhi upasagga paccaya ādīhi ca pabbajja ādayaḥ saddāḥ nippajjante  paṭhamam eva vajitabbā ati pabbajjā iñjanam ejjā samajjanam samajjā nisīdanam nisajjā  vijānanam vijjā visajjanam visajjā padanam pajjā hananam vajjhā esanam icchā  atiesanam aticchā sadanam sajjā sayanti ettha ati seyyā sammā cittam nidheti etāya ati

original: iccevamādīhi sakāritehi ca yuṇvūnaṃ paccayānaṃ ana ānana aka ānanakādesā honti yathāsaṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: i t ca ivamādīhi sa kāritehi ca paccayānam ana ānana aka ānana ka ādesāḥ honti yathāsaṅkhyam
translated: The following are the forms of the nouns in the above list with the verbal nouns ending in ana, āna, ākā, āka, and ānana respectively:

analyzed: kattari bhāva karaṇesu ca
translated: in the passive voice, in the causative, and in the verbal nouns.

original: Kattari tāva – panudatīti panūdano. Evaṃ sūdano, janano, savaṇo, lavano, havano, pavano, bhavano, ñāṇo, asano, samaṇo.
analyzed: kattari tāva panudati iti panūdanaḥ evam sūdanaḥ jananaḥ savaṇaḥ lavanaḥ havanaḥ pavanaḥ bhavanaḥ ñāṇaḥ asanaḥ samaṇaḥ
translated: In the passive voice: panudati = panūdanaṃ, sūdanaṃ, jananaṃ, savaṇaṃ, lavanaṃ, havanaṃ, pavanaṃ, bhavanaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, asanaṃ, samaṇaṃ.

original: Bhāve ca – panudate panūdanaṃ. Evaṃ sūdanaṃ, jananaṃ, savaṇaṃ, lavanaṃ, havanaṃ, pavanaṃ, bhavanaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, asanaṃ, samaṇaṃ, sañjānanaṃ, kuyate kānanaṃ.
analyzed: bhāve ca panudate panūdanam evam sūdanam jananam savaṇam lavanam havanam pavanam bhavanam ñāṇam asanam samaṇam sañjānanam kuyate kānanam
translated: In the causative: panudate = panūdanaṃ, sūdanaṃ, jananaṃ, savaṇaṃ, lavanaṃ, havanaṃ, pavanaṃ, bhavanaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, asanaṃ, samaṇaṃ, sañjānanaṃ, kuyate = kānanaṃ.

original: Kārite ca – phandāpīyate phandāpanaṃ, cetāpīyate cetāpanaṃ, āṇāpīyate āṇāpanaṃ.
analyzed: kārite ca phandāpīyate phandāpanam cetāpīyate cetāpanam āṇāpīyate āṇāpanam
translated: In the passive causative: phandāpīyate = phandāpanaṃ, cetāpīyate = cetāpanaṃ, āṇāpīyate = āṇāpanaṃ.

original: Karaṇe – nudanti anenāti nūdanaṃ, evaṃ sūdanaṃ, jananaṃ, savaṇaṃ, lavaṇaṃ, havanaṃ, pavanaṃ, bhaganaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, asanaṃ, savaṇaṃ.
analyzed: karaṇe nudanti anena ati nūdanam evam sūdanam jananam savaṇam lavaṇam havanam pavanam bhaganam ñāṇam asanam savaṇam
translated: In the verbal nouns: nudanti = nūdanaṃ, sūdanaṃ, jananaṃ, savaṇaṃ, lavaṇaṃ, havanaṃ, pavanaṃ, bhavanaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, asanaṃ, savaṇaṃ.

original: Puna kattari – nudatīti nūdako, sūdatīti sūdadhakā, janetīti janako, suṇotīti sāvako,
analyzed: puna kattari  nudati iti nūdakaḥ sūdati iti sūdadhakā janeti iti janakaḥ suṇoti iti sāvakaḥ
translated: In the causative: nudati = nūdako, sūdati = sūdhakā, janetīti = janako, suṇoti = sāvako,

original: lunātīti lāvako, juhotīti hāvako, punātīti pāvako, bhavatīti bhāvako, jānātīti jānako,
analyzed: lunāti iti lāvakaḥ juhoti iti punāti iti pāvakaḥ bhavati iti bhāvakaḥ jānāti iti jānakaḥ
translated: He cuts off, thus he is a cutter (lāvaka); he offers, thus he is an offerer (hāvaka); he purifies, thus he is a purifier (pāvaka); he becomes, thus he is a becomer (bhāvaka); he knows, thus he is a knower (jānāka);

original: asatīti asako, upāsatīti upāsako, sametīti samako.
analyzed: asatī iti upāsatī iti upāsako sameti iti samakaḥ
translated: he is not, thus he is a non-being (asaka); he worships, thus he is a worshipper (upāsaka); he is the same, thus he is the same (samaka).

original: Kārite tu – phandāpayatīti phandāpayako. Evaṃ āṇāpayako, cetāpayako, sañjānanako.🔽642, 588. I ya ta ma ki e sāna’mantassaro dīghaṃ kvaci du sa ssa guṇaṃ do raṃ sakkhī ca.
analyzed: kārite tu phandāpayati iti phandāpayakaḥ evam āṇāpayakaḥ cetāpayakaḥ sañjānanakaḥ  i ya ta ma ki e sa antassaraḥ dīgham kvaci du sa ssa guṇam do raṃ sakkhī ca
translated: But in the case of the causative: he causes to be shaken, thus he is a shaker (phandāpayaka). In the same way, he causes to be ordered, thus he is an orderer (āṇāpayaka); he causes to be thought, thus he is a thinker (cetāpayaka); he causes to be known, thus he is a knower (sañjānanaka).

original: Iya ta ma ki e saiccetesaṃ sabbanāmānamanto saro dīghamāpajjate, kvaci dusaiccetassa🔽dhātussa ukāro guṇamāpajjate, dakāro rakāramāpajjate, dhātvantassa sassa ca sa kkha
analyzed: iya ta ma ki e saic ca itesam sabbanāmānam antaḥ saraḥ dīgham āpajjate kvaci  dhātussa ukāraḥ guṇam āpajjate dakāraḥ rakāram āpajjate dhātu antassa sassa ca sa kkha
translated: The long vowel in the case of the words beginning with i, ya, ta, ma, ki, e, sa, ic, etesam, sabbanāmānam, ananto, saro, dīgham, kvaci, du, sa, ic, cetassa,

original: īiccete ādesā honti yathāsambhavaṃ. Ete saddā sakena sakena nāmena yathānuparodhena
analyzed: ī i cca ete ādesāḥ honti yathāsambhavam ete saddā sakena sakena nāmena yathā an uparodhena
translated: guṇam, do, ra, sakkhī, ca, is lengthened. The vowel u in the case of the word beginning with dhātu, is shortened. The vowel da in the case of the word beginning with dakāro, is shortened. The vowel ra in the case of the word beginning with rakāram, is shortened. The vowel s in the case of the word beginning with dhātvantassa, is shortened. The vowel i in the case of the words beginning with sa, kkhī, ic, etesam, ādesam, is lengthened. These sounds are formed again in the Dispensation of the Buddha in the following way, according to the meaning of each word,

analyzed: buddha sāsane pacchā puna nippajjante
translated: in the order in which they occur.

original: Imamiva naṃ passatīti īdiso, yamiva naṃ passatīti yādiso, tamiva naṃ passatīti tādiso,
analyzed: imam iva nam passati iti īdisaḥ yam iva nam passati iti yādisaḥ tam iva nam passati iti tādisaḥ
translated: He sees it as this, thus he is such-like (īdiso); he sees it as that, thus he is that-like (yādiso); he sees it as thus, thus he is thus-like (tādiso),

original: mamiva naṃ passatīti mādiso, kimiva naṃ passatīti kīdiso, etamiva naṃ passatīti ediso,🔽samānamiva naṃ passatīti sādiso. Imamiva naṃ passatīti īriso, yamiva naṃ passatīti🔽yāriso, tamiva naṃ passatīti tāriso, mamiva naṃ passatīti māriso, kimiva naṃ passatīti🔽kīriso, etamiva naṃ passatīti eriso, samānamiva naṃ passatīti sāriso. Imamiva naṃ🔽passatīti īdikkho, yamiva naṃ passatīti yādikkho, tamiva naṃ passatīti tādikkho,🔽evaṃ mādikkho, kīdikkho, edikkho, sādikkho. Īdī, yādī, tādī, mādī, kīdī, edī, sādī.

original: 643, 635. Bhyādīhi mati budhi pūjādīhi ca tto.🔽Bhīiccevamādīhi dhātūhi, mati. Budhi pūjādito ca tta paccayo hoti.
analyzed: bhi ādīhi mati budhi pūjā ādīhi ca tto  bhī it ca evamādīhi dhātūhi mati budhi pūjā āditaḥ ca tta paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The suffixes mati, buddhi, and tta are added to bhaya, etc., and to pūjā, etc.🔽The suffixes mati, buddhi, and tta are added to roots such as bhaya, etc., and to pūjā, etc.

original: Bhāyitabboti bhīto, supitabboti sutto, mijjitabbo sinehetabboti mitto, sammannitabboti🔽sammato, saṃ suṭṭhu mānitabbo pūjetabboti sammato, sammānīyitthāti sammato, saṃkappīyateti🔽saṅkappito, saṃkappīyitthāti saṅkappito, sampādīyateti sampādito, sampādīyitthāti🔽sampādito, avadhārīyateti avadhārito, avadhārīyitthāti avadhārito, bujjhitabbo ñātabboti🔽buddho, ajjhayitabboti ito, etabbo gantabboti ito, viditabbo ñātabboti vidito, takkīyateti🔽takkito, pūjīyateti pūjito, pūjīyitthāti pūjito, apacāyitabboti apacāyito, mānitabbo
analyzed: bhāyitabbaḥ iti bhītaḥ supitabbaḥ iti suttaḥ mijjitabbaḥ sinehetabbaḥ iti mittaḥ sammannitabbaḥ iti 🔽sammataḥ sam suṭṭhu mānitabbo pūjetabbo iti sammataḥ sammānīyittha ati sammataḥ saṃkappīyate iti 🔽saṅkappitaḥ saṃkappīyittha ati saṅkappitaḥ sampādīyate iti sampāditaḥ sampādīyittha ati 🔽sampāditaḥ avadhārīyateti avadhāritaḥ avadhārīyittha ati avadhāritaḥ bujjhitabbaḥ ñātabbaḥ ñātabbaḥ iti 🔽buddhaḥ ajjhayitabbaḥ iti itas etabbaḥ gantabbaḥ iti itas viditabbaḥ ñātabbaḥ iti viditaḥ 🔽takkito pūjīyateti pūjitaḥ pūjīyittha ati pūjitaḥ apacāyitabbo ti apacāyitaḥ mānitabbo
